Table 1 MXene cocatalysts utilized until now for photocatalysis along with their applications and function as cocatalyst. MXene cocatalyst Photocatalytic application Function as a co-catalyst Nb2CT x Photocatalytic H2 generation • Extreme work function of Nb2CT x i.e., 4.1 eV Nb2CT x as compared to other transition metal carbides for improved H2 evolution • The difference in Fermi level of Nb2CT x with other semiconductor like TiO2 allows the formation of Schottky junction for efficient separation. • The metallic conductivity makes it act as a good electron separator Ti2CT x Photocatalytic H2 generation • Works as an efficient reduction cocatalyst • Shows efficient charge separation when forms heterojunction with semiconductors Ti2C2T x Photocatalytic H2/O2 generation, Photocatalytic CO2 reduction, Photoelectrochemical water splitting/Photodegradation • Acts as a channel for the transferring of photogenerated electrons • Offer formation of Schottky junction for efficient charge transfer • Promote charge carrier’s separation • Offer increased light utilization due to its dark colour • Offer improved surface area • Consist of increased active sites for photoreaction • Provides shorter diffusion length for the charge carriers Table 2 Summary of the advantages and disadvantages of synthesis methods of Ti3C2 MXene [11,38,97–101]. Synthesis method Advantages Disadvantages Direct HF etching • HF etching can be operated easily and can be employed at the low reaction temperature • The direct HF method has given the highest potential and is considered a primary method in synthesizing Ti3C2T x MXenes. • The –OH terminating group through this technique may convert Ti3C2 into TiO2 that directly enhances the catalytic photocatalytic activity taking advantage of the heterojunction formation. • Water intercalates the MXene layers which expands their space and weakens interactions. • Complete removal of Al layer is obtained through this method • HF is highly corrosive, toxic and adverse environmental effects • The usage of HF requires extra attention • This is not practicable for industrial scale production as it will highly impact the ecological system • The etched Ti3C2 has a high amount of —F terminal groups on the surface that are unfavorable for photocatalytic applications In situ HF etching • Operated easily and requires low energy consumption. • Less chemical risk during the etching process • The metal cations in the etching solution can be embedded between the MXene sheets to increase the spacing between the sheets which weakens the interaction between the layers, useful to the delaminate MXene. • Layering of MXene may occur without an additional intercalation agent, thereby-one can obtain a single layer or a few layers of MXene phase flakes. • No lateral defects are formed • In addition, it can also be etched with ammonium bifluoride which may reduce the application of additional intercalation steps. • No need for sonication to delaminate Ti3C2T x MXene sheets, unlike in the direct HF technique. • Direct delamination of Ti3C2T x MXene into single–layer sheets through the intercalation of the fluoride ions, provide higher specific surface areas, reaction stability and plentiful exposed redox–active sites, conducive to improvement in the redox activity • Accompanied by intercalations of water molecules, thus leading to a longer drying time. • When MXenes produced by the in-situ HF forming etching are dried, the interlayer spacing will significantly decrease due to the disappearance of interlayer water molecules • Raising the content of the –F groups result in the decrease of the interlayer water molecules and the interlayer spacing. • The process may result in the unetched MAX phase residues that require a systematic approach to enhance the product yield. Electrochemical etching • Green and safe synthetic method with low energy consumption. • Low reaction temperature and therefore low energy consumption with minimal corrosive acid usage • Minimizes the hazardous content of fluoride–based solutions. • Etching does not require any fluoride ions that produce MXenes with only –Cl, –O, and –OH terminal groups depending on the type of electrolyte utilized. • The presence of –F terminal could be controlled to fit specific application requirements. • The –F terminal group could be controlled for specific application requirements. • The flakes obtained have lateral sizes much larger than those synthesized through HF etching beneficial for certain applications. • The synthesized Ti3C2T x MXene flakes contain only –O and –OH termination groups without any presence of –F terminations. • Treating Ti2AlC under a higher cathodic potential may strip away both the Al and Ti layers causing the formation of carbide–derived carbon formation. • The use of unsuitable electrolytes could affect the structure of the obtained MXenes. • The fabrication of surface Carbide derived carbons (CDCs) that hinders the subsequent etching process. The toxicity of intercalators employed is a safety concern. • The etching process results in a low yield of MXenes inappropriate for large–scale synthesis. Alkali etching • The produced Ti3C2T x MXenes do not result in the formation of the –F termination group. • Alkali treatment without employing any acid/fluorine solution synthesizes high–purity Ti3C2T x MXenes • The synthesized method has the possibility to enhance the oxidation stability. • The active sites on the surface of the Ti3C2T x MXenes could be modulated which may improve the catalytic performance. • The fluorine–free nature may provide more –OH and –O terminations. • The employment of concentrated alkali and high temperature restrict its application for large–scale MXene synthesis. • The obtained MXenes are multilamellar with the polar organics accordion–like structure that needs further intercalation and delamination for the generation of single–layer MXene nanosheets. • The Al (oxide) fabricated through the reaction of OH– blocks further extraction of Al that results in the hindrance of the formation of the MXene known as the “jamming effect”. Water–free etching • Reduce the limitations of the Ti3C2T x MXenes in water–sensitive applications • Ti3C2T x MXenes prepared through this route exhibit higher interlayer spacings compared with etching in water. • Ability to control the terminal group distribution. • The replacement of water with a polar organic solvent. could reduce the presence of the –OH terminating group resulting in an improvement of the stability of the MXenes. • The use of organic solvents to synthesize MXene requires a long etching time • Needs to be operated in a glove box to guarantee an anhydrous environment whereas multi–step washing operations are required to remove the byproducts and residual acidic propanol detergents that cause inconvenience to the operation. Molten salts substitution • This approach preferred MXenes formation with a –Cl terminal group, which was noted to be more stable than the –F terminal MXenes. • Molten salt etching method is the first choice for the synthesis of MXenes with high formation energy such as nitride MXenes. • Since the type of molten salt determines the terminations, it is necessary to develop fluorine–free molten salt etching methods. • Beneficial for the utilization of Ti3C2T x MXenes as high–rate negative electrode materials for electrochemical energy storage, as the presence of –Cl terminal groups offer excellent oxidation stability • Although the molten salt etching method has a broader etching range and chemical safety, however, it requires in–depth research to the physical and chemical properties of produced MXenes, e.g., electrical conductivity, hydrophilicity and mechanical property. • The fabricated MXenes have accordion–like structures that need further treatment for forming nanoscale complexes. • The synthesized MXenes have a complex surface group combination that results in a broad gap between theoretical predicated properties and realistic behavior. Halogen etching • Improve the role of MXene in electronic applications. • The halogen etching method not only provides more solutions for controlling the surface chemistry to modulate the properties. • Allows us to have a deeper understanding of the etching mechanism of MXene • The MXene flake sizes synthesized through Halogen etching were larger than the MXene prepared through HF etching • Needed to be further treated with an aqueous HCl solution to delaminate the multilayer structure and the remove of remaining AlI3. Graphical abstract Recent advances in titanium carbide (Ti3C2) MXenes with various synthesis approaches and influential parameters are disclosed to stimulate charge separation efficiency. The synthesis environment, parameters, etchings agents, intercalation and heterojunction formation have influential effect on maximizing photocatalytic CO2 reduction and hydrogen production efficiency. Photocatalytic solar to energy conversion is considered an attractive approach for overcoming energy crises and environmental concerns. Recently, titanium carbide (Ti3C2) MXenes have been recognized as promising cocatalysts based on their metallic conductivity, excessive active reaction sites, and enlarged surface area. The current review focuses on the properties and applications of Ti3C2 MXenes useful in the field of photocatalysis. More specifically, surface modification of Ti3C2 MXenes by varying synthesis parameters to get pure materials and also composites with the role of functional groups towards solar energy conversion applications is highlighted in this review. The effect of etching and oxidizing pathways to get an efficient cocatalyst has been discussed in detail. Considering the significant effect of parameters, optimum synthesis conditions such as etchant type, concentration, time and type of intercalant in both the Ti3C2 synthesis approaches for improved photoactivity are discussed. Additionally, the surface modification of Ti3C2 through oxidation for TiO2 growth on its surface is deliberated with a detailed discussion on etchant type, concentration, etching time, and environmental factors. The optimum oxidation condition, including temperature, time, and environment for thermal treatment of Ti3C2, were also included. Lastly, the review summarizes the conclusion and future perspectives for solar energy conversion applications. Keywords Solar to energy conversion Ti3C2 nanomaterials Termination groups MXene cocatalyst Synthesis parameters 1 Introduction Solar to energy conversion has been considered as an ideal approach for overcoming the energy crisis, excessive fossil fuel consumption and environmental concerns [1]. Since 1972, researchers have been studying TiO2 for UV-assisted water splitting and the use of photocatalytic reactions for solar-to-energy conversion [2,3]. In this regard, the properties of a photoactive semiconductor used as a photocatalyst material are of great significance, whereas, it should be capable of utilizing photogenerated electrons and holes in carrying out redox reactions. Moreover, the efficiency of photosystem is dependent on the efficient light utilization and electron hole pairs separation properties [4,5]. Semiconductors when used as a single material exhibit low visible absorption and limitation of charge carrier’s recombination [6]. However, the efficiency of single materials can be effectively boosted through the formation of heterojunction, composites with other semiconductors, metal doping, and loading cocatalyst. Among the variety of co–catalysts employed in photocatalytic activity enhancement, nanotubes of carbon, graphene (GO), carbon QDs, and noble metals are being explored. However, there still lies a gap in exploring cost effective and effectual cocatalysts for improving efficiency as well as for upscaling the photocatalytic applications at an industrial scale [7–9]. Titanium carbide (Ti3C2) MXene due to its 2D layered structure drawn attention worldwide in the area of energy storage and conversion [10,11]. Specifically, MXene Ti3C2 fabrication occurs due to selective etching of Al layers from the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase and has become a hotspot research area for the widespread application of MXene–based photocatalysts [12]. At the time of etching, the surface of MXene Ti3C2 is covered with functional groups (–OH, –O and –F) from the etchant used in the process [13]. Ti3C2 MXene offers promising characteristics such as higher specific area, terminal functional groups, mechanical properties, electronic properties, and electrochemical characteristics [14]. These distinct properties aid Ti3C2 in photocatalytic applications such as electro/photocatalytic water splitting [15,16], photocatalytic CO2 reduction [17], and waste water degradation [18], lithium and sodium ion batteries [19,20], supercapacitors [21], and bio and gas sensors [22,23]. In a photocatalytic reaction, the boosted surface area with termination in form of functional groups promotes Ti3C2 in creating a Schottky junction to avoid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers [24]. In addition, it provides more exposed metallic active sites on its surface which are beneficial in higher reactivity [25] and offer high electron conductivity, which makes them efficient in charge carrier transportation and separation [26]. Also, MXene is considered as a favourable electrode material in devices employed for energy storage owing to the terminal transition metal atoms present on the surface and the highly conductive metallic carbide in the core [27]. Moreover, due to different Ti3C2 morphologies constituting different shapes and dimensions, it has been known to depict extended application as a photocatalyst in photocatalytic energy conversion applications. The layered accordion like structure of Ti3C2 MXene has been converted to other dimensions such as ultrathin 2D nanosheets, 3D structures of Ti3C2 MXene, one-dimensional (1D) nanorods and nanowires, and zero–dimensional (0D) quantum dots. Also, Ti3C2 MXene can be utilized as a platform to load a variety of 2D, 0D, and 1D photocatalyst materials for the production of renewable and efficient solar fuels [28]. The synthesis of Ti3C2 can be achieved through different etching agents for the removal of the Al layer. The structure and morphology of Ti3C2 are strongly dependent on numerous parameters, including type and concentration of etching agent, reaction time, intercalation agents, and synthesis conditions. These parameters can modify the properties such as conducting and semiconducting properties, termination groups, defect morphology and structure of Ti3C2 MXene. The properties can influence the quality, environmental stability, and properties of as produced Ti3C2 [29,30]. In addition, the performance of Ti3C2 MXene can be enhanced by the modification of properties which are: i) Numerous functional beneficial for the construction of intimate contact interface with other semiconductors,; ii) The bandgap alignment of Ti3C2 modulated for tuning the surface chemistry; iii) The conductive metal cores in the layered structure with excellent metallic conductivity and electron acceptance ability; iv) tuneable terminal groups and surface defect; and v) tuneable electronic and optical properties. Thus, Ti3C2 MXene has been combined with a large number of materials for energy conversion applications [31]. Moreover, because of the presence of Ti3+ in Ti3C2 MXene, it can act as a source for the production of TiO2 material. Typically, during the in-situ growth of a TiO2 onto Ti3C2 composite in contact with heterojunction, the following possibility of interaction can be formed i.e., creation of multiple heterojunctions, ii) Schottky junction formation at the interface, iii) Z–Scheme and S–Scheme heterojunctions, iii) intimate interfacial interaction prevailed as key factors for energy conversion applications [32]. A lot of review papers have been published that summarize the progress in the preparation and applications of MXenes as photocatalysts [33–38]. However, none of them explain in detail the effect of parameters on the synthesis and modification of Ti3C2 MXene, TiO2/Ti3C2 MXene and its composites. Herein, recent developments in synthesis methods with alternation of parameters for surface modification of titanium carbide MXene have been demonstrated. The surface modification of Ti2C3 through different approaches such as etching and thermal oxidation with varying parameters such as etchant type, concentration, time, temperature and environment is systematically discussed. Firstly, the fundamental structure and properties of Ti3C2 MXene for photocatalytic energy conversion applications are deliberated. The role and recent advancement of Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst for charge separation are also deliberated with the existence of various functional groups such as –OH, –O and –F. The effect of various parameters for synthesizing Ti3C2 by etching and oxidation with the effect of parameters for in-situ grown TiO2 NPs are discussed in detail. The review also discussed the effect of parameters to optimize them through etching and thermal oxidation of Ti3C2 to maximize photoactivity. Later on, the application of MXene based materials in the fields of photocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction are explained. Finally, the conclusion and future perspective are also included in the review. 2 Overview and fundamentals 2.1 Structural characteristics MXenes are recognized as a developing class of two–dimensional materials containing transition metal carbides and nitrides. These 2D materials are synthesized by etching of MAX parent material (M n +1AX n ) where, M = Mo, Ti, Zr, Cr A = Al, Ga, Ge, Si; and X = C, N [39]. The general formula of MXene with terminations is M n +1XT x where, M = Mo, Ti, Zr, Cr; X = C, N and T denote the presence of specific functional groups as shown in Fig. 1 . The first MXenes reported by Naguib et al., were the pioneers of exploring and studying the structural properties of MXenes, i.e., Ti3C2 [12]. Usually, MXenes constitute a hexagonal closed–packed crystal structure but various MXene show different sequence M atoms such as, in the case of M2X the hexagonal closed–packed structure is in a sequence ABABAB whereas, M3X2, and M4X3 have face center cubic sequence (ABCABC) [39]. There are many MXenes explored and reported, which have been synthesized and investigated already, including Ti2C, Cr2TiC2, Ti3CN, MO2C, Ti3C2, Zr3C2, Ti4N3, V2C, and Mo2ScC2 [40]. Out of different MXenes, Ti3C2 is recognized as a hotspot for MXene based photocatalysts, etched from hexagonal compressed MAX parent (Ti3AlC2) material through the breaking of weak Ti–Al bonds while the firm Ti − C bonds remain intact along with the preservation of the parent material’s hexagonal structure [41,42]. Moreover, the type of synthesis method adopted for the etching along with the type of etchant used, pH conditions, and the temperature of treatment influence the nature and distribution of terminations [43]. Moreover, the MXenes are considered superior 2D materials as compared to other 2D materials-like graphene based on their hydrophilic nature and metal like electric conductivity. 2.2 Optical and semiconducting characteristics In general, MXenes have outstanding characteristics like elevated young modulus, thermal conductivity, electric conductivity, and flexible band gaps. Interestingly, MXenes are considered to have metal-like, semi–metal like, and semiconductor-like nature [48]. More specifically, the electronic property of MXenes is tenable by simply tuning the terminations in the form of functional groups, adjustment in morphological features, and by composite formation, leading to higher conductivity. This conductivity is similar to graphene oxide however, it is higher than reduced graphene oxide and other C-based materials [49]. For instance, a conductivity in the range of 850 to 9880 S cm−1 is held by Ti3C2T x , which can be attributed to the changes in the MXenes flakes d–spacing, termination groups, delamination, the lateral sides rise and defects are governed by the amount of etchant and the time of etching [50]. The transmittance of MXenes has also been reported to be dependent on the etchant, leading to the generation of different terminations. This can be explained by MXenes etched by HF and NH4HF2, where the NH4HF2 etched MXenes were reported to have higher transmittance. Halim et al., reported spin–coated MXene films constituted transmittance of 97% per manometer, which was comparable to the single layered GO [51]. In another study, an increase in transmittance of Ti3C2T x from 74.9 to 92% was reported using tetramethyl ammonium hydroxide instead of urea, hydrazine and dimethyl sulfoxide [52,53]. Moreover, a 5 nm thick film of Ti3C2T x is known to show absorption in the UV–Visible region, i.e., wavelength 300–500 nm, and showed 91.2% of transmittance. Moreover, a film thickness dependent absorption of irradiation in 700–800 nm wavelength was also reported and it was recognized as a significant greenish photocatalysts for photothermal applications [54]. For photocatalytic applications, the band gaps of MXenes influence the optical property of the material governed by the type of structural property, compositional property, and terminations. Generally, the band gap of MXenes ranges from 0.05 to 2.87 eV and can be tuned by modifying the presence of terminations. Most of the MXenes constitute an indirect band gap like Sc2C, having values of 1.8, 1.03, and 0.45 eV with the presence of terminations –O, –F, and –OH, respectively [55]. This opens up the ability to tune the structural properties of MXenes for photocatalytic processes. 2.3 Ti3C2 MXene as a cocatalyst Ti3C2 is known to act as a cocatalyst in various photocatalytic applications and can be used as a precursor for the synthesis of photocatalyst materials [56]. Usually, MXenes are used as a substrate, and are combined with zero–dimensional (0D) – 2D materials with MXene nanosheets to form MXene heterostructures. However, in some cases, MXene is reduced to nanosize and is dispersed on the surface of conjugate materials. Both types of structures cause a synergistic effect between the components in the heterostructure to improve the energy storage and conversion performance [57]. Though, various MXenes are available to be considered for photocatalytic processes involving CO2 reduction, H2 production and photodegradation however, out of 100 different MXenes explored like Mo2ScC2, Mo2C, (Nb0.8Zr0.2)4C3, (Nb0.8Ti0.2)4C3, Nb2C, Nb4C3, TiNbC, Ta4C3, Ti4N3, (V0.5Cr0.5)3C2, and V2C, Zr3C2, mostly Ti3C2T x MXene based cocatalyst in nanocomposites are studied for photocatalytic applications [58]. Table 1 summarizes the MXene cocatalysts that have been utilized until now for photocatalysis along with their applications and functions as cocatalysts. The ability of Ti3C2 to act as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic applications lies in its characteristics, including structural properties, metal-like conductivity, enlarged surface area, and existence of surface functional groups. The metal-like conductivity and lower Fermi level are vital properties of Ti3C2, which make it act as an electron acceptor by forming a Schottky barrier to support efficient charge separation. On the other hand, the improvement in photocatalytic ability of Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst is achieved by modification of morphological and structural properties. Moreover, multi-layered Ti3C2 also acts a support to grow and finely disperse other photocatalysts onto its surface whereas, the delamination of Ti3C2 into nanosheets results in photocatalysts with fewer dimensions like 0D, 1D and 2D with a greater interface which have more surface area and active sites e.g., 0D Ti3C2 QDs [35]. In the present section, the role of Ti3C2 to act as an ideal cocatalyst for photocatalysis is briefly discussed. Generally, conductive metals like Pb, Pt, Au, and Ag with large work functions have been utilized for the transfer of electrons from the semiconductor material because of the building up of an electric field which, leads to the separation of charge carriers through the formation of a Schottky barrier. However, the less cost–effectiveness and less availability for industrial use of these metals makes it less applicable towards various applications [59]. Remarkably, the adjustable band gap of Ti3C2 and electron accepting ability for charge carrier separation make it an ideal cocatalyst. Moreover, the tuneable band gap also provides an achievable unoccupied molecular orbital and the highest occupied molecular orbital, which can be modified more for photoactivity enhancement. Also, Ti3C2 constitutes a work function higher than other semiconductors in the composite, the electrons tend to transfer from a lower to a higher Fermi level until they achieve equilibrium. The photogenerated electrons are migrated and accepted by Ti3C2 to carry out a reduction reaction while the holes are oxidizing in the other material acting as a semiconductor [60]. Moreover, to initiate the photogeneration of charge carriers, light harvesting is considered vital, which is excellently fulfilled by Ti3C2 due to its dark black colour. As soon as it absorbs the light irradiation, the generation of electron hole pairs takes place, whereas, furthermore, adding to the ability of Ti3C2 to capture the electrons, the Ti3C2 potential differences with semiconductors accelerate charge transfer for reduced recombination [61]. In this regard, Ti3C2 acted as a cocatalyst with g–C3N4 to promote photocatalytic activity. One–step calcination was carried out to obtain 2D/3D g–C3N4/Ti3C2 with good interfacial contact by Schottky barrier formation for electron accepting in Ti3C2 [62]. In another work, a 1D CdS/2D Ti3C2 heterojunction was developed with a strong interface through the in-situ assembling of CdS nanorods onto ultrathin Ti3C2 nanosheets. The low Schottky barrier was formed, which led to efficient charge carriers’ separation by transferring electrons to conductive metallic Ti3C2. This enabled seven times to increase in H2 generation as compared to the pristine CdS [60]. Recently, Zeng et al., reported that pure Cd0.5Zn0.5S showed rapid recombination of charge carriers, whereas, upon introducing Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst, the band edge of Cd0.5Zn0.5S were bent upwards to form a Schottky junction for the improved charge transfer and separation due to the built–in electric field [63]. Another study discussed the promotion of degradation and CO2 reduction by CeO2/Ti3C2 MXene. The CeO2 and Ti3C2 constituted work function of 4.69 and 5.78 eV, respectively, which upon contacting transfer electrons from CeO2 to Ti3C2 via Schottky barrier by electric field as shown in Fig. 2 (a). The photocatalytic degradation and CO2 reduction were 6.3 and 1.5 times higher than CeO2, respectively [64]. One pot hydrothermal process was employed to intercalate Ti3C2 nanosheets onto porous UiO–66–NH2 MOF. Upon illumination by irradiations, UiO–66–NH2 generated electron hole pairs were separated due to –O functional groups on Ti3C2 due to a positive Fermi level and relatively low |ΔG H*| value, leading to transferring of electrons from MOF to Ti3C2 through Schottky barrier [65]. Apart from the electron-accepting ability of Ti3C2, it also acts as an electron donor in various photocatalytic processes. The electron donor ability of Ti3C2 is originated when the TiO2 are formed on the surface of Ti3C2 through oxidation process which has a more increased work function than Ti3C2, making the photogenerated holes remain in Ti3C2 for oxidation reaction, while the electrons are migrated [66,67]. As mentioned earlier, the photocatalytic ability of TiO2 has been researched a lot due to its appropriate band positions, non–toxicity, stability and cost–effectiveness. The hybridization of Ti3C2 with grown TiO2 showed six folds increased photon–to–current efficiency in comparison to pure TiO2. During the photocatalytic activity, Ti3+ was formed on the contact interface of Ti3C2/TiO2, leading to the removal of electrons, whereas Ti3C2 plays the role of a hole accumulator for the inhibition of charge carriers [68]. Zhuang et al., studied 1D/2D TiO2/Ti3C2 by electrostatic self–assembly and was observed to generate hydrogen of 6.979 mmol h−1 g−1 with the support of Pt. The interface of TiO2 and Ti3C2 supported the transfer from TiO2 to Ti3C2 followed by transfer to Pt for reduction reaction while holes remained in TiO2 [66]. Other than the combination of TiO2/Ti3C2, other semiconductors are also employed with TiO2/Ti3C2 for photocatalytic applications. In this regard, Ai et al., studied synergic effect of Ti3C2 (TiO2)@CdS/MoS2 hybrid towards visible light induced H2 production from the lactic acid. In the case of Ti3C2 (TiO2)@MoS2, the Ti3C2 and MoS2 contained TiO2 sandwiched between them, whereas in the case of Ti3C2 (TiO2)@CdS/MoS2, TiO2 was grown onto Ti3C2. This hybrid supported a multi pathway for the separation of electron hole pairs by forming a Type II heterojunction and Z–scheme between CdS/MoS2 and TiO2/CdS in which electrons generated in Cd were migrated from CB of CdS toMoS2 while holes were migrated to Ti3C2, where the process of oxidation took place to obtain TiO2 as shown in Fig. 2(b). This leads to the prolonging of electron lifetime and charge carrier separation [69]. In another work, Ti3C2 as a conductor with BiOBr without the formation of Schottky junction effectively, thus stimulates the photocatalytic pollutant degradation and H2 generation. In this work, Ti3C2 constituted a more negative work function, i.e., −0.09 eV vs. NHE as compared to CB potential. As the non–existence of Schottky junction, the migration of electrons from conductor material to BiOBr was not supported, however, the bending occurred at the contact point of both the materials in which the negative potential electrons were involved in the reduction reaction. Instead of electron accepting, the holes migrated from BiOBr to Ti3C2, leading to inhibition of recombination as demonstrated in Fig. 2(c) [70]. Multi–layered and single layered Ti3C2 have been widely known as a host and robust matrix for the assembling of various semiconductors like g–C3N4, oxides of metals, metal sulfide, MOFs and perovskite for photocatalytic processes [71]. In this regard, Cheng et al., reported the even dispersion of 2D lamellar g–C3N4 onto Ti3C2 by one-step calcination of Ti3C2 with melamine at 550 °C under N2 as a precursor for g–C3N4 and as an exfoliator gas for exfoliating Ti3C2 to obtain a 2D/3D structure. This helped in improving the photocatalytic H2 generation based on the charge carriers separation through the Schottky junction and due to the conductive behaviour of Ti3C2 [62]. Moreover, the electronegativity of Ti3C2 for the absorption of metals makes it a host for the growth of metal sulfides. Also, ternary chalcogenides are well known to be grown on Ti3C2, leading to photocatalyst with good electronic properties, appropriate band edge position, the presence of defects and flexible optical ability [72]. In another work, a quasi–alloying effect at the interface of Zn2In2S5 and Ti3C2 was generated when the S2− anions from the thioacetamide reacted with the adsorbed In3+ and Zn2+ onto Ti3C2. The quasi–alloying effect was responsible for the generation of an electric field at the interface junction, leading to effective charge carriers’ separation. Also, synergistically improved photocatalytic H2 generation and degradation was attributed to the conductivity of Ti3C2 and the visible light response of Zn2In2S5 [73]. The activity of TiO2 towards photocatalysis has been seen to improve after utilizing Ti3C2 as a host or platform for TiO2, causing it to overcome its limitations of charge recombination, less visible light absorption, and slow kinetics [74]. Moreover, other than acting as a host for the growth of TiO2, it also acts as a precursor for growing TiO2 by in-situ growth process [74]. A ternary nanocomposite 1T–WS2@TiO2@Ti3C2 with Ti3C2 as a host was constructed by Li et al., for the photocatalytic H2 evolution of 3409.8 μmol g–1 h−1 [75]. Similarly, photo–deposited Cu2O nanodots on the TiO2 surface in (001) TiO2@Ti3C2 were studied for HER. As shown in Fig. 2(d), only Cu2O NPs having –1.4 CB and TiO2 nanosheets having CB at –0.3 eV and having exposed (001) facets formed a p–n heterojunction. The electrons migrated from the CB of Cu2O to the TiO2 CB, while holes moved in the opposite direction. Upon the introduction of Ti3C2 having –OH and a few –F termination groups as Ti3C2(OH) x , the photogenerated holes were taken by Ti3C2(OH) x , while the electrons migrated to TiO2/Cu2O interface. Next, Cu2O was transformed into Cu as a reduction cocatalyst as the small diameter of Cu2O made the electrons to break the energy barrier and photogenerated electrons were moved from TiO2 CB to Cu2O as shown in Fig. 2(e and f). In this dual–carrier–separation mechanism, the roles of electron facilitator and cocatalyst were played by Cu atoms while Ti3C2 acted as holes and played the role of hole mediator, leading to efficient charge separation as discussed in Fig. 2(g) [76]. Finally, the most common function of Ti3C2 is its ability to form interface contact with other semiconductor materials, resulting in the formation of Schottky and p-n junctions for effective charge carrier separation. In addition to using Ti3C2 as an electron acceptor cocatalyst with a single material, Ti3C2-based complex and hybrid heterostructures have been studied to be highly effective in photocatalytic applications due to the strong contact at the interface, improved light response, and charge separation. Furthermore, the Ti atoms on Ti3C2Tx play the role of nucleating sites to promote growth of TiO2 on its surface, leading to the construction of an interfacial heterojunction, i.e., 2D Ti3C2/TiO2 for inhibiting charge recombination. The use of other co-catalysts, such as MoS2 and Cu, in conjunction with Ti3C2, results in dual-carrier separation, which is an entirely new concept for improving photocatalytic efficiency. A developing aspect of MXene material is the use of multi-layered Ti3C2 as a host to support and disperse other semiconductors, leading to the formation of hybrids with improved charge migration and overall efficiency. 2.4 Role of Ti3C2 functional groups The etching of the Al layer out of the parent MAX material in the presence of an etchant at normal temperature is the most commonly adopted approach for synthesizing MXenes. Generally, the Al layer from the MAX parent material, i.e., Ti3AlC2, is etched to obtain Ti3C2T x [77]. The possibility of breaking the flexible M−A bonds is more in comparison to the metallic nature of the strong M−X bonds [78]. Moreover, the T elements are likely to be preferable for surface functionalization based on electrophilic property which has a direct effect on the physical and chemical properties of the synthesized MXene. Furthermore, the exfoliation of multi–layered MXenes is reported to be achieved by the utilizing polar organic solvents such as isopropanol and dimethyl sulfoxide and an intercalant. Sonicating the MXenes with the solvents and intercalant will aid the intercalation of the intercalant into the multi layered structure and will lead to the expansion of interlayer spaces to transform the multi-layers into single-layered; few-layered or flaked structures of MXene [79]. As shown in Fig. 3 (a and b), after HF etching, the layered Ti3C2 partially contained functional groups (–OH, –O, and –F) as termination along with intrinsic defects. Moreover, after annealing in air, the Ti on Ti3C2 oxidized due to the presence of –O, leading to the formation of surface TiO2 [80]. (1) M n +1 AX n +3HF/AIF 3 +M n +1 X n +1 .5H 2 (2) M n +1 X n +2H 2 O/M n +1 X n (OH) 2 +H 2 (3) M n +1 X n +2HF/M n +1 X n F 2 + H 2 O Various studies report the use of HF for etching Ti3AlC2 along with functional group formation. However, there is still a lack of research on the mechanism study of the functional groups covered by Ti3C2 for photocatalysis. For instance, a study reported the preparation comparison between the traditional HF etching method and a hydrothermal approach with NaBF4 as an etchant and reported the generation of –OH group termination in both synthesis approaches, whereas, the elemental distribution of the Ti3C2 prepared by hydrothermal approach depicted –F group, resulting from adsorbed F [81]. In another work on photocatalytic H2 generation, HF was utilized in etching of Ti3AlC2 into Ti3C2 with –O and –F functional groups, however, when the prepared Ti3C2 was hydrothermally combined with other materials for CdLa2S4 composite formation, all the –F was transformed into –O [72]. Peng et al., explored the existence of –OH termination for HF etched Ti3C2 where the –OH terminations offered an ultra–low work function beneficial for efficient charge migration and acted as a hole trapper in photocatalytic degradation [82]. Likewise, another study reported the effect of terminations, especially –OH on attaining a low work function, i.e., 1.6 eV [83]. Xie et al., reported the etching of Ti3AlC2 into Ti3C2, followed by annealing at a lower temperature. The Ti3C2 was found to be covered with –H, –OH and –F surface terminations in form of multiple single layers. However, at lower concentration of HF, the –F groups were reduced. The Li storage of –OH functional group was observed to hold insufficient capacitance, whereas, –O terminations were observed to have more capacitance. The –OH functional groups can be reduced to improve the capacitance by annealing [84]. Similarly, the annealing of MXene under hydrogen may be utilized for removing –F and converting –OH to –O termination group. The annealing of MXene was advantageous because it resulted in faster ion transport and increased the active sites exposed to the electrolyte [85]. Wastewater treatment was carried out by the heterojunction of BiPiO4/Ti3C2 in which the hydrophilic terminations –O and –OH originated, acting as a material to bind the two semiconductors without any other agent [86]. He et al., synthesized Ti3C2 quantum dots with TiO2/g–C3N4 for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The Ti3C2 after exfoliation from MAX was treated with dimethyl sulfoxide followed by sonication for 12 h in an N2–protected environment along with the use of ammonia to control pH around 9. This led to the generation of –OH, –NH, =O and –F terminations. The quantum dots offered well dispersion onto g–C3N4 due to the binding of heterojunction aided by the terminations and also acted as a highway for charge transport [17]. The generation of functional group –O onto Ti3C2T x has been studied by using HF with 6 mol L−1 and 15 mol L−1, as depicted in Fig. 3(c), the –O has been observed to be higher by using 6 mol L−1 HF than 15 mol L−1. This causes a higher amount of H2O molecules in between the layers of Ti3C2T x which makes more H+ reachable to the active sites [81]. In another work, g–C3N4/Ti3C2 studied for enhancement in photocatalytic H2 generation was related to the presence of functional group –F on Ti3C2 due to the treatment with HF. However, the –F was removed due to its unstable nature on high annealing temperature, while forming heterojunction with g–C3N4 and was converted to –O. The –O terminations were tested to have a lower Femi level than Ti3C2 and Ti3C2 with F– functional group. Moreover, under the annealing process, the Fermi level of Ti3C2 achieved was more negative as compared to that of g–C3N4, leading to charge separation by electron transfer from g–C3N4 to Ti3C2, where more active sites were also present in the form of terminations [62]. The Ti3C2 MXene was synthesized by etching with NaF and HCl solution, causing the formation of many terminal groups such as –O and –OH. This Ti3C2 was coupled with Ag3PO4 for photodegradation, which was effective due to the strong termination supported interface between both materials along with electron transport and improved photoactivity as shown in Fig. 3(d) [87]. Zhang et al., also recognized the usefulness of functional groups including –O and –OH with negative charges on Ti3C2T x for photodegradation based on the enlarged provision of surface area and hydrophilic nature [88]. In another work, the functional groups containing Ti3C2 were identified to be used as an alternate for noble metal and as co–catalyst due to its metal like nature and narrow band gap [89]. The coupling of Ti3C2 with ZnS contained –O/–OH functional groups converted from –F after hydrothermal treatment with ZnS as a cocatalyst was reported to exhibit charge transport, separation, leading to improved photoactivity with stability [89]. The presence of functional groups may also regulate the crystal growth during the formation of composite materials. For instance, during the synthesis of Co(CO3)0.5OH·0.11H2O@MXene (CoCH@MXene) layered composite, the CoCH crystal growth was regulated due to the chemical interaction between Co2+ and the hydroxyl functional groups on the Ti3C2T x MXene surface in the CoCH@MXene composite, causing the formation of a sandwich–like structure with the presence of interwoven CoCH wires in-between Ti3C2T x MXene layers. The interwoven CoCH wires with reduced particle size promoted ion diffusion kinetics and thwarted the MXene layer stacking and increased the ion diffusion path in the CoCH@MXene composite [90]. Overall, the existence of terminal groups on Ti3C2 is known to be highly photoactive, however, the Ti3C2 with functional groups as terminations has not been researched much. On the other hand, researching the location, quantity, and ratio of various terminations can improve the stability of Ti3C2 along with its optical properties, ensuring its improved catalytic activity. Fig. 4 summarizes the advantages of Ti3C2 MXene with functional group terminations for photocatalytic applications. 3 Effect of parameters on synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene Different synthesis methods have been employed for the formation of Ti3C2 MXene, such as direct HF etching, in-situ HF etching, electrochemical etching, water free etching, molten salt substitution, and halogen etching etc. Each of these methods has its own advantages and disadvantages that have been discussed in Table 2 . These methods are affected by certain parameters such as etching agent, acid/etchant concertation, etching time, intercalants employed, and synthesis conditions. The effect of parameters such as type of etching agent, etching concentration and reaction time can affect the properties of the synthesized Ti3C2. These properties include structural, chemical, and electronic properties that may consequently affect the catalytic properties of Ti3C2. The effect on structural properties includes the type of structure, spacing between the layers, and complete or partial removal of the Al layer from the MAX parent. Moreover, the Ti3C2 layered structure has the ability to be transformed into ultrathin 2D single nanosheets and 0D quantum dots (QDs), leading to the possibility of designed multi–functional photocatalysts. The morphology and size of photocatalyst material greatly influence the properties and functions of the photocatalysts. The decrease in particle size of MXene may result in the loose stacking structure, improved water wetting properties, increased electrical conductivity and ion conductivity, and increased energy density and power density. A specific structure is obtained through a change in spacing between layers and obtaining structures such as 3D, 2D, or 0D structures. The change in chemical properties is obtained through the change in the surface terminating groups, including oxygen (–O), hydroxyl (–OH) or fluorine (–F). The parameters that changed during the synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene [92] also affect the electronic properties (metal or semiconductor), band gap, thermodynamic stability, intercalation mechanisms, and the ability of MXenes to store energy. Ti3C2 MXene can adsorb gases due to its abundance of highly active functional sites, hydrophilic nature, and large surface area [93]. Adsorption can take place via physisorption, chemisorption, or Kubas-type binding. For physisorption, the adsorbent material should have i) a high specific surface area and ii) a suitable binding energy (0 eV for endothermic reaction and strong binding) [94]. The adsorption is dependent on defects that may act as electron traps, decreasing the adsorption energy [95]. The defect formation may allow gases to interact directly with the MXene surface through a spontaneous and exothermic process. Moreover, the adsorption of gases is dependent on the thickness of the layer, which may result in enhanced selectivity toward specific gases. For example, increasing the layer thickness of MXene to 20 nm could make it easier to separate H2 and CO because H2 is more selective than CO2 due to the difference in their kinetic diameters (2.89 and 3.3) [96]. 3.1 Effect of etching agent Until now, numerous etching agents have been explored that are illustrated in Fig. 5 (a), the most common of which are HF, HF with NH4HF2, LiF in HCl, LiCl in HF, HCl in NaBF4, etc. Moreover, LiF can be replaced by other salts such as NaF, KF, and CsF. Recently, transition metal-fluorides such as FeF3 and CoF2 have been used, as have non-fluorinated agents such as alkali-based compounds. Other methods include electrochemical etching and etching with molten salts. The selection of the etching agent has a huge impact on the surface chemistry, oxidation sensitivity, hydrophilic properties, delamination ability, conductivity, nature of inserted cations, size of flakes, and degree of defects, among other properties [102]. The etching agent strongly modifies the nature of surface terminal groups (–F, –OH and/or –O), oxidation sensitivity, delamination ability, nature of the inserted species, interstratification, concentration of defects and size of flakes [102]. The effect of LiF and HCl etching on the formation of delaminated Ti3C2 has been illustrated in Fig. 5(b). It is obvious that initially, multilayer Ti3C2 is achieved, which can be further converted to delaminated Ti3C2 through an ultrasonic approach. Fig. 5(c–f) depicts the effect of HF etching on the formation of Ti3C2. It could be seen that HF etching can produce layered Ti3C2 MXene. However, morphology is entirely dependent on the time of etching. The detailed information about etching time has been illustrated in the next sections. The role of Ti3C2 MXene as a cocatalyst in the presence of TiO2 for photocatalytic CO2 reduction has been demonstrated in Fig. 5(g). All the above discussions confirmed that types of acid and other operating parameters are very important to control structure and morphology with higher photoactivity. 3.2 Effect of acids/etchant concentration MXenes exhibit varying properties depending on the concentration of etchant. Different concentrations of etching agents can be used for etching purposes, either in situ or ex situ, producing Ti3C2 MXene. Upon increasing the concentration of etchant for the selective removal of the “A” element, etchant time reduces and an accordion–like morphology of Ti3C2 can be obtained. Munir et al., compared the concentration effect of HF on the formation of Ti3C2. From the XRD in Fig. 6 (a) it is determined that 5% HF has a lesser tendency to react with MAX resulting in the unsuccessful formation of MXene. With the increase in the concentration of HF to 10%, a weak peak of MXene (002) originated at 8.89°, which became stronger at HF concentrations of 20%, 30%, and 40%. The lower shift in basal planes and origination of (002) peak was because of surface terminations on MXene and the removal of Al from the MAX phase. Meanwhile, the intensity of the characteristic peak (104) belonging to MAX starts decreasing and the MXene peak (002) shifts in the backward direction with the increase in concentration as given in Fig. 6(b). The etching conducted using 30% HF was almost similar to those using 40% HF solution and demonstrated that an increase in concentration can etch the MAX phase in less time. Fig. 6(c) reveals the uneven surface of the MAX phase. At lower HF concentrations, such as 5%, 10%, and 20%, an accordion like morphology was not dominant as shown in Fig. 6(d–f). However, an accordion–like morphology was obtained when 30 and 40% HF solutions were used for etching as demonstrated in Fig. 6(g and h), respectively [30]. Similarly, in another research, HF solutions of different concentrations such as 20, 40, and 49 wt%, were employed to exfoliate Ti3AlC2 and study was conducted to identify the effect of exfoliation on the morphology and structure of the obtained Ti3C2. The densely stacked sheets structure of Ti3AlC2 layers began to separate after 20 wt% HF etching; however, the layers remained stacked compared with Ti3C2 obtained after 40 wt% and 49 wt% of HF etching. The average thickness of a layer was 60 ± 5 nm, corresponding to roughly 30 monolayers of Ti3C2 MXene. When exfoliated by 40 wt% HF, the thin laminae of Ti3C2 MXene was formed, and the layer spacing of Ti3C2 MXene increased to 90 ± 10 nm. However, it was smaller than that of 130 ± 20 nm layer spacing achieved from etching by 49 wt%. It can be interpreted from the discussion that the increase in HF concentration causes an increase in the layer spacing [106]. In the study of the effects of acid concentration on the performance of Ti3C2 MXene, Alhabeb et al., prepared three different HF concentrations of 5, 10, and 30 wt% and disclosed that different concentrations of HF acids would result in different morphological structures of Ti3C2 MXene [29]. The optimal control of acid concentrations undeniably affects the structural properties and photocatalytic performance of Ti3C2 MXene. It was highlighted that a low concentration of HF (5 wt%) was able to break the A element from the MAX phase but showed poor morphological properties of Ti3C2 MXene. Increasing the HF concentration until an optimal concentration of 30 wt% was observed to produce a higher quality of Ti3C2 MXene having an accordion–like structure. Fig. 6(i–k) depicts the morphological structure of MAX and Ti3C2 MXene at different HF concentrations (30 wt% and 5 wt%). It was noted that the control of acid/etchant concentration for the synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene is a compelling criterion to achieve the high quality of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. Naguib et al. were the first to peel off MAX to make MXene by using 50% HF, and the etching of Al was further confirmed by XRD analysis, as shown in Fig. 6(l) [12]. The shift in the XRD peak from 40° to 10° confirmed the replacement of –OH and –F terminal groups. Therefore, HF acid at 50% was considered the best concentration and was introduced for the etching of other MAX phases. Additionally, the effect of different acid concentrations was substantially studied to further understand the correlation between the structural stability of the produced Ti3C2 MXene with the etchant concentration. Besides, a different study indicates that a higher HF concentration (100%) during the etching process firmly forms ternary fluorides instead of MXene nanosheets [108]. Besides, Zhu et al [109] studied the effect of the mass ratio of Ti2AlC2 to HF having a 10% concentration. The MXene that was treated with a mass ratio of 1:2 had better capacitance and rate capability than electrodes made of Ti3C2Tx or other carbon-based materials.The better performance was attributed to the excellent electron conductivity and layered Ti2CT x structure, which lowered the overall resistance and made it easier for electrons to move. Moreover, Lipatov et al., revealed that the synthesis condition of Ti3C2 MXene strongly affects its electronic and chemical properties [107]. It was observed that increasing the etchant concentration propitiously facilitated the etching process and favoured the formation of high structural quality with a clean, uniform Ti3C2 MXene layer. AFM data revealed the relationship between the morphology of Ti3C2 MXene flakes and their structural stability, as shown in Fig. 6(m). It was concluded that a slow degradation process with high maintaining stability is exhibited by the high quality of Ti3C2 MXene flakes. Studies have found that defect formation is highly linked to the improved properties of the Ti3C2 MXene. It has been revealed by Sang et al., that defects are mainly formed during the etching process [110]. In fact, the etchant concentration is the main factor in the formation of the defects. Besides, adjusting the concentration of HF acids could lead to the formation of the defects. The increase in the HF concentration resulted in a higher concentration of defects in Ti3C2 MXene, which positively influenced the chemical and structural stability of Ti3C2 MXene. The way the functional groups of MXenes interacted with the defects was another way to improve their photocatalytic performance [111,112]. Therefore, the etchant concentration should be meticulously studied to produce a high quality of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. The shape and crystal structure of the made Ti3C2 MXene are both good for its stability as a catalyst and as an optoelectronic material. Huang et al [113] observed that under the condition of a high concentration of hydrochloric acid leads to the expansion of the interlayer distance of Ti3C2. The solution of concentrated hydrochloric acid contains more hydrogen ions, which means it has stronger oxidation, and this makes it easier to oxidize the Ti element. The increase in interlayer distance may result in an increase in photocatalytic activity. It is determined that the properties such as morphology, groups attached, redox properties, defects, conductivity properties, and etching time of the MXene are dependent on the concentration and type of etchant used for etching MAX. These properties ultimately affect the photocatalytic activity. The results confirm that etchant concentrations can facilitate the dissolving of high Al (oxide) hydroxides and prevent the oxidation of Ti species. Because of the low water containment in this reaction system, –OH and –O groups can form on the surface of as prepared Ti3C2 MXene. For instance, Qiao et al [114] studied the effect of functional groups on the photocatalytic activity of semiconductors. The O–terminated Ti3C2 has shown a near–zero value for moderate H adsorption free energy, which is much lower than the commonly used H2 production cocatalyst, Pt (–0.09 eV), showing its high photoactivity towards H2 production. The photocatalytic H2 production of the optimized O–terminated Ti3C2/CdS was extremely highest with 14,342 μmol h−1 g−1, which was higher than NiS–CdS, Ni–CdS, Pt–CdS and MoS2–CdS. All these findings confirm that acid concentration has an important role in the performance of MXene efficiency as a cocatalysts due to the alternation of morphology and termination groups. 3.3 Effect of etching time It is very important to understand the influence of the etching time on the morphology, structure, surface terminations, electrochemical and photochemical properties. Apart from etching concentration, the exfoliation of Ti3C2 is strongly dependent on etching time. By increasing the etching time, Ti3C2 nanosheets were gradually delaminated and more C was exposed. The longer etching time led to better conversion of Ti3AlC2 to Ti3C2 MXene but a higher concentration of defects on the Ti3C2 MXene. For etching time, the etching concentration is a prerequisite as a high HF concentrated solution requires less time for etching than a lower concentrated solution of HF. Gogotsi et al., studied that 2 h of time was enough to remove the Al layer out of Ti3AlC2 with concentrated HF (∼50 wt%) at room temperature [115]. At different HF concentrations of 30, 10, and 5 wt% also showed removal of Al, but low concentrations of HF (5 wt%) required 24 h to selectively etched aluminium from MAX. Also, dissimilar concentrations of 10 wt% HF and 30 wt% HF required 18 h for etching. However, the accordion–like morphology of particles is usually observed when ≥10 wt% HF solution was used for etching [29]. With increased etching time, Ti3C2 nanosheets were slowly delaminated, which enlarged the specific surface area, but also accompanied the destruction of the natural octahedral structure of Ti3C2 for loss of Ti and more C were exposed on the surface. The reduction in etching time can also be achieved by employing any mechanical treatment, such as ultrasonic treatment, that may reduce the etching time. In this regard, Feng et al., [116] observed that the peaks of Ti3AlC2 diminished with increasing time, disappearing after 24 h without ultrasonic treatment and 4 h with ultrasonic treatment. Mashtalir et al., [117] studied the removal of the Al layer through the changes in the sheet resistivities of cold pressed MXene discs as a function of etching time. A dramatic increase in resistivity was observed during the first 2 h of the reaction. This was attributed to the replacement of the Al layers, which are metallically bonded, with more insulating oxygen or OH ligands, which are presumably covalently bonded to the Ti3C2 layers and interact only via weak hydrogen and/or van der Waals bonds. However, no other significant changes were observed for the next 8 h, but the resistivity increased after 10 h of etching. Apart from this, since MXenes have good in–plane but poor out of plane conductivities, it causes slow oxidation of the MXene as it resides longer in the etching solution. Oxidation has also been linked to the formation of an insulating titanium oxyfluoride (TiOF2) phase. It can be determined that enhanced etching time may result in an increase in delamination, providing more reactive surface area for catalyst. However, the increase in etching time may also cause oxidation of Ti3C2, resulting decrease in conducting properties. The effect of etching time has been conducted, but it is not sufficient to conclude the discussion to reach a point with concluding remarks. Another reason is the effect of time has integrated with many other parameters that could affect the time required to complete the etching process for obtaining the required Ti3C2 MXene. 3.4 Effect of different types of intercalants The distinct features of MXene can be discerned through their unique multilayer structure, surface terminal sites that facilitate the redox reaction, and excellent electrical conductivity similar to solution–processed graphene [118]. The use of etchant can achieve delamination. However, to convert it into a monolayer or quantum dots cannot be achieved through etchant. Therefore, intercalants are employed in combination with sonication to achieve single layered Ti3C2 structure or quantum dots. The conversion of bulk Ti3C2 into monolayer and Ti3C2 quantum dots through delamination results in an increase in exposed surface area. Moreover, some novel properties such as quantum confinement, edge effect, surface functionality, strong redox capability, and abundant exposed metal sites are incorporated into the structure formed as shown in Fig. 7 . These properties are conducive to the activation and acceleration of CO2 photoreduction and H2 production [119]. The delamination of Ti3C2 MXene has been achieved by the chemical intercalation of large organic molecules such as Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [60], Tetraalkylammonium hydroxides [120], lithium ions, and isopropylamine [121]. Other intercalating agents used are ethanol, tetrahydrofuran, thiophene, acetone, chloroform, toluene, hexane, and dimethylformamide (DMF). It is also reported that the delamination process could be directly achieved during the synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene from MAX phase, depending on the intercalant and the etchant used. Fig. 8 (a) illustrates the schematic representation of Ti3C2 MXene delamination. The selection of intercalants for the delamination of Ti3C2 MXene multi–sheet depends on the synthesis routes mentioned previously. The concentration of Ti3C2 MXene sheets in the solution depends on the type of intercalant used in weakening the interlayer of the Ti3C2 MXene. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) is one of the most widely used intercalants for the delamination process. Separating the Ti3C2 MXene multi–sheets through the addition of DMSO is generally performed when the exfoliation of MAX to Ti3C2 MXene was accomplished through direct HF etching. Generally, the addition of DMSO is followed by sonication to separate the stacked Ti3C2 MXene into a single layer [122]. According to Kannan et al., the optical properties of Ti3C2 MXene fundamentally depend on the sheet's thickness and the ions intercalation [123]. The intercalating DMSO, urea, and hydrazine decreased the Ti3C2 MXene film thickness, affecting the transmittance properties of the Ti3C2 MXene. Different intercalating agents used in the delamination process will result in different interlayer spacings. It has been reported by Lv et al., that the addition of DMSO as an intercalant could increase the specific surface area, improve the electrical conductivity and increase the interlayer space of Ti3C2 MXene [120]. Accordingly, Mashtalir et al., observed an expansion in the interlayer of Ti3C2 MXene after the addition of DMSO [124]. Out of the intercalating agents used for the delamination, such as ethanol, tetrahydrofuran, thiophene, acetone, chloroform, toluene, hexane, and DMF, only DMSO and urea show higher expansion of the interlayer space. For the affirmation, the increase of d–spacing in the Ti3C2 MXene from 9.8 Å to 17.6 Å by using DMSO can be observed from the XRD pattern as shown in Fig. 8(b) [125]. Comparatively, it has been reported by Xu et al., that treating Ti3C2 MXene with DMF offered the highest interlayer expansion and least oxidation effect than those in ethanol and DMSO [126]. It was observed that the use of DMSO as the intercalant is generally subjected to long intercalation, sonication time, and repeated centrifugation. Studies done on DMSO as an intercalant revealed that it could only delaminate Ti3C2 MXene and could not intercalate with other types of MXenes [113]. Therefore, different approaches have been developed to overcome this limitation, such as combining etching with the delamination process. Treating Ti3AlC2 with HCl and LiF could directly synthesize a single layer of Ti3C2 MXene in which the cations in the fluoride salts could intercalate into the Ti3C2 MXene interlayer and directly delaminate them. The assistance of the sonication process depends on the concentration of HCl and LIF used during the synthesis process. It was highlighted that no sonication is required with the milder and minimal HCl and LIF concentrations used [29]. This route is considered the simplest route to delaminate multilayer Ti3C2 MXene and is highly favoured, especially in optical and electronic applications, as it results in defect–free and large Ti3C2 MXene flakes. In another study, Naguib et al., reported that by using TBAOH as an intercalating agent, large quantities of delaminated MXene could be achieved compared to those with DMSO [121]. Unlike DMSO, TBAOH has been reported to only delaminate other types of MXene such as V2CTz, Ti3CNTz, Ti4N3Tz, and Mo2CT, but it is not helpful in exfoliating Ti3C2 MXene into a single layered sheet [125]. Despite all the claims, Alhabeb et al., suggest that the intercalation of large ions of TBAOH is possible by extending the stirring time to 2.5 days. Prolonging the stirring time delaminated Ti3C2 MXene into a single layer. Therefore, the type of intercalating agent is one of the important criteria in the delamination process of Ti3C2 MXene. The types of intercalants used mainly dependent on the selected synthesis route. Intercalants are required, especially in the direct HF etching, to weaken the bonds between the layers and separate the layer of stacked Ti3C2 MXene into individual sheets. Besides, direct delamination could be achieved during the etching process without the addition of intercalants, simply by the addition of HCl and LIF combination as an etchant. Appropriate selection of the intercalants could reduce the delamination time, yield different quantities of delaminated MXene and improve its quality. This is in accordance with the study done by Su et al., who discovered an exceptional improvement in the hydrogen generation by monolayer Ti3C2 MXene with 2.5 times the enhancement than its multilayer counterpart. To study the effect of Ti3C2T x on the photocatalytic activity of TiO2, the photocatalytic hydrogen generation was conducted by employing the Ti3C2T x /TiO2 composite, which showed superior photocatalytic activity than that of pure TiO2, due to the promotional effect of Ti3C2T x on the separation of photogenerated charge carriers. In addition, the H2 evolution rate increased with the content of monolayer Ti3C2T x up to 5.0 wt% and the 5–TC/TO sample. When single layer Ti3C2T x performance was compared with multilayer Ti3C2T x through the addition of 5.0 wt% to the TiO2 sample, it was determined that the single layered has higher performance as compared to multi–layered Ti3C2T x as shown in Fig. 8(c) [127]. He et al., obtained edge–terminated zero–dimensional (0D) Ti3C2 MXene quantum dots (TCQD) that were subsequently integrated with TiO2 nanosheets and g–C3N4 through electrostatic interactions. The composite formed resulted with maximum of 4.39 and 1.20 μmol g−1 h−1 for CO and CH4 production rates which were more than three and eight times higher than the production rates observed for TiO2 as shown in Fig. 8(d). The edge modification of TCQD favoured the intimate coupling with g–C3N4 that improved catalytic reactivity and provided additional surface reaction active sites. Wang et al., [128] observed that on employment of Zn2+ ions to intercalate into MXene through an electrochemical method induced a shrinkage of the adjacent MXene layers. The pre–intercalated Zn2+ ions resulted in loss of lost electrons while Ti of MXene gained electrons. Moreover, low quantity of –F surface functional groups was attained. 3.5 Effect of the synthesis conditions Parameters such as synthesis temperature, pH and reaction time predominantly affect the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX to Ti3C2 MXene. The exfoliation may decrease the particle size of MXene, which results in increase in specific surface area, loose stacked structure, improved water wetting properties, enhanced electrical conductivity and ion conductivity beneficial for photocatalytic system energy storage materials [131]. In a study on the effect of reaction temperature on the synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets, Zhang et al., reported that increasing the reaction temperature from 30 to 55 °C facilitates the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX [129]. This was confirmed through the XRD patterns observed in Fig. 8(e), indicating that as the temperature increased to 55 °C, complete exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX was achieved. This is in agreement with the study conducted by Cui et al., indicating that increasing the reaction temperature substantially improved the exfoliation degree [132]. Comparatively, the different studies conducted by Yang et al., investigated the effects of different synthesis temperatures and times on the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX with HCl and LiF as etchant [133]. It was disclosed that the optimum synthesis temperature to exfoliate Ti3AlC2 MAX completely is 60 °C with 48 h etching time. This contradicts other research outcomes, which generally signified that the complete exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX could be achieved at an optimal temperature of 35 °C with 24 h of etching time. Even though the higher temperature is explored for facilitating the exfoliation to form Ti3C2 MXene sheets, the increasing temperature was observed to show no significant effect on the interlayer distances of the Ti3C2 MXene. Controlling the interlayer expansion is significant for ion intercalation, especially in the electrochemical energy storage field and other energy-relative applications [134]. In the case of the direct delamination process without the addition of intercalants, the reaction temperature should be concisely studied as increasing the specific reaction temperature could promote the delamination process. The association of the reaction temperature with the expansion of the Ti3C2 MXene interlayer has been investigated by varying the temperature from 30 to 55 °C [129]. The highest interlayer expansion was observed in the sample etched at 35 °C with c value of 27.77 Å. Increasing the temperature up to 55 °C did not significantly increase the interlayer distances of the Ti3C2 MXene. This hypothetically explains that increasing the etching temperature is not specifically involved in affecting the interlayer expansion of the Ti3C2 MXene, but the washing solution used accordingly results in different interlayer distances. For the affirmation, the effect of different washing solutions was studied to attest to the role of washing solution on the Ti3C2 MXene. It was noted that the use of ethanol as a washing solution increased the interlayer spacing in Ti3C2 more than washing by distilled water. Besides, washing the Ti3C2 MXene with ethanol could result in a better morphological structure in which the exfoliation is more discerned, as shown in Fig. 8(f–g). Many studies have reported the utilization of water as the primary solvent for the etching and delamination processes. However, Natu et al. discovered that the presence of water inhibits the synthesis of specific quantum dots on MXene sheets, prevents certain polymerisation reactions, and reduces the performance of lithium-ion batteries [135]. Therefore, the substitution of water with different organic solvents has been investigated. It was demonstrated that in the presence of ammonium dihydrogen fluoride, the etching and delamination of Ti3AlC2 MAX to Ti3C2 MXene can be accomplished. The dissociation of NH4HF2 into NH4F and HF in the presence of the polar solvent could facilitate the exfoliation and delamination process, producing fluorine rich termination Ti3C2 MXene flakes. Moreover, the dissolved HF acted similar to water mixture. So, the study of different solvents for treating acids could lead to alternatives to MXene for uses that are sensitive to water. In the synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets, several criteria such as the reaction temperature, etching time, type of treatment, and washing solvent should be assiduously studied. This is because alteration in the synthesis condition will affect the performances and the quality of the produced Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. Besides, different reaction temperatures will optimize the delamination and exfoliation processes. Higher etching temperature and less etching time will lead to better conversion of Ti3AlC2 MAX to Ti3C2 MXene [31]. Additionally, the use of organic solvent serves the same role as water and does not considerably affect the produced Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets. It was hypothesized that treatment using organic solvent could also exfoliate different types of MAX phases and increase the relevancy of MXene in various technological applications. It can be determined from the study that the effect of synthesis conditions has a very strong effect on the photocatalytic activity of the composite formed through the combination with Ti3C2. For instance, Li et al [130], found that the Ti3C2 obtained through HF etching when washed with water has the presence of abundant functionalities –F, –OH, and –O). However, when the obtained Ti3C2 was first disposed of with NaOH solution and then washed with deionized water, the product obtained contained –OH and –O functionalities. It was observed that the hydrogen production of TiO2/Ti3C2 synthesized from Ti3C2 with an abundance of –F terminated groups was considerably higher than that of Ti3C2 with –O and –OH terminated functional groups samples by a factor of 2. The increase in photocatalytic activity was due to the formation of (001) facets formed during the calcination of Ti3C2, as shown in Fig. 8 (h). 4 Synthesis of in-situ grown TiO2 over Ti3C2 MXene As a compound of titanium and carbon, Ti3C2 offers a new basis to construct the heterojunction between carbonaceous, Ti3C2 and TiO2 material [136]. During the formation of TiO2, the Ti3C2 provided a Ti source and a nucleating site without the addition from outside. The surface of Ti3C2 is oxidized in the presence of water and air. Hence, Ti3C2 can be used as a precursor for TiO2 and as a carrier for other oxides, forming an atomic scale interfacial heterojunction with intimate contact [137]. The composite provides various benefits, as illustrated in Fig. 9 such as high number of reactive sites, a greater ability to reflect and scatter light, a reduction in the diffusion length of photogenerated holes and electrons, and reduced electron–hole recombination. The Ti3C2 as an electron reservoir suppresses the recombination of electron–hole pairs on TiO2 nanoparticles and improves the accumulation of electrons employed for multi–electron reaction. Moreover, the intimate interaction developed from in-situ growth is important to accelerate the transfer of electrons from TiO2 to Ti3C2 generated through a photoinduced process [138]. The oxidation of Ti3C2 is dependent on several factors, including temperature, the chance of exposure to O2, structural defects in the as–synthesized Ti3C2 and the functional groups on the surface. Moreover, by manipulating the selection of the type of etching agent and its concentration, time of oxidation, the phase composition and morphology of TiO2 can be controlled [139]. 4.1 Effect of types of acids The formation of in situ grown TiO2 during the formation of Ti3C2 MXene oxidation for equivalent treatments in water is attributed to the different surface chemistry of the MXene depending on the etching environment. The type of acid used has a strong effect on the nature of surface terminal groups (–F, –OH and/or –O) that later on, through thermal treatment, result in the formation of different phases of TiO2. For instance, Wang et al [140] compared the formation of TiO2 during the etching of Ti3AlC2 to Ti3C2 using different types of acid such as, HF, HCl with FeF3 and HCl with LiF. We were able to get a lot of titanium to oxidize on the surface of MXene made with FeF3/HCl. This is likely because Fe3+ partially oxidized the titanium during the etching, which helped the titanium oxidize when it was put in water. The selectivity towards the formation of anatase, which is crucial in photocatalysis, for instance, is nevertheless promoted using the FeF3/HCl etching environment, whereas the rutile form is favoured with LiF/HCl. In addition, the oxidation rate of the FeF3/HCl samples, which is greater than that of the LiF/HCl samples, can be controlled by the duration of immersion in water, leading to the formation of various ratios of TiO2/Ti3C2. Such a combination of the control of both the anatase and rutile formation and the oxidation rate give great flexibility in the design of TiO2@Ti3C2 nanocomposites. When Li et al. [141] used HF with HNO3, they got Ti3C2@TiO2 with a bigger gap between the layers than when they used HF with H2O2. Also, the TiO2 particles grew evenly between the accordion-shaped gaps in the Ti3C2 MXene [102]. Peng et al., synthesized oxidation of layered Ti3C2 assisted by NaBF4. It formed a Schottky junction with the (001) surfaces of n–type semiconductor TiO2 [142]. In another work, TiO2/Ti3C2 was formed through the in-situ oxidation in the etching process. The effects of concentrations of hydrochloric acid on the etching process found that HCl with higher quantity resulted in an increased quantities of TiO2 [113]. Xu et al., [143] employed HCl and NaBF4 to prepare a layered hybrid heterojunction of TiO2/Ti3C2. These layered TiO2/Ti3C2 heterojunction materials constituted a narrow band gap (2.1 eV), which contributed to the absorption of visible light. 4.2 Effect of acid concentrations The change in acid concentration has a strong effect on the quantity of TiO2 formed due to the oxidation process. The acid concentration allows the modification and distribution of terminal groups like –O/–OH ratio as well as the stability against surface oxidation that results in TiO2 formation. For instance, at lower HF concentrations, the formation of MXenes with higher activity is favoured, probably due to its lower –F content [102]. Also, the concentration of acid may affect the formation of TiO2 phases such as anatase and rutile. Compared with low concentration of acid solution, the highly concentrated acid solution comprises more hydrogen ions and stronger oxidation capability, making the oxidization process of Ti element in the Ti3C2 easier. Zhao et al, [144] observed faster oxidation at lower pH as compared to a higher pH value. The possible reason was attributed to the defect formation caused by the MXene surface after reacting with a strong acid. Huang et al., [113] observed that the in-situ oxidation of Ti3C2 was larger at higher concentration of hydrochloric acid, resulting in formation of larger quantity of TiO2. Khan et al., [145] etched Ti3AlC2 with 39% and 49% concentrated HF and observed that the quantity of TiO2 was higher in 49% concentrated HF than 39%. Moreover, it was observed that by increasing the concentration of HF, the amount of TiO2 (anatase) formed was higher as compared to TiO2 (rutile) that was higher for lower concentration of HF as shown in Fig. 10 (a). It was observed that the Ti3AlC2 when etched with 49% HF showed higher photocatalytic activity as compared to 39% HF etched Ti3AlC2 towards syngas production. When the Ti3C2 with the presence of higher content of TiO2 was coupled with the g–C3N4 resulted further advancement in syngas production due to the synergic effect of TiO2, Ti3C2 and g–C3N4 as shown in Fig. 10(b and c). 4.3 Effect of etching time The TiO2 formation is dependent on the etching time as the oxidation occurs with time to produce TiO2. The oxidation may occur due to O2 adsorption that acts as an oxidizer under coordinated Ti atoms in Ti3C2 for bulk TiO2. Naguib et al., [146] have postulated the reactions of HF with Ti3AlC2, resulting in the formation of Ti3C2. The increase in etching has an effect on the structure of Ti3C2 that may result in the formation of TiO2. The increase in etching time may cause destruction of the crystal structure of Ti3C2T x MXene and promote the formation of numerous defects on the surface and edges. The formation of defects results in the oxidation process, leading to TiO2 formation. As the reaction time increases, the interlayer spacing becomes larger and the surface for oxidation is exposed. Mashtalir et al., [147] observed that in the presence of dissolved oxygen, delaminated Ti3C2T x single flakes reacted with water to produce TiO2. The surfaces and edge positions of Ti3C2T x were oxidized in the presence of O2 at room temperature to produce TiO2 during the etching process. However, it was observed that the process may also occur in the absence of dissolved oxygen but, with a slower reaction. The conversion of Ti3C2T x layers into nanoscale TiO2 may lead to an increase in the accessible surface area. Benchakar et al., [148] observed that large flakes of Ti3C2T x are obtained when etched for little time, whereas increasing the etching time led to reducing flake size with more disorganized stacks and defective sheets. Similarly, Khan et al., [145] also studied the effect of etching time on TiO2 and it was observed that with the increase in etching time the quantity of TiO2 was increased.
