Also, Tahir et al., [105], observed during the etching process for 24 h, the formation of TiO2 only occurs on the external surface possibly be due to exposure of only Ti3C2 external surface with oxygen under continuous stirring. The effect of growth of TiO2 has been demonstrated on the etching time has been demonstrated in Fig. 10(d). By extending the etching time to 96 h the formation of TiO2 occurs both on external and internal surface. However, maximum growth of TiO2 nanoparticles at the Ti3C2 surface can be attained until 48 h and any increase in the etching time beyond this reaction time would result in loss of the Ti3C2 sample due to its continuous conversion. The detachment of TiO2 nanoparticles from the MXene surface was noticed as white powder at the upper surface of the suspension. 4.4 Effect of environment The oxidation of two–dimensional Ti3C2 MXene structures has been considered strongly dependent on the environment for the formation of TiO2. The high oxidation rate of Ti3C2 would result in the formation of a large quantity of TiO2. The oxidation of Ti3C2 can be improved through the proper selection of etching acid, oxidizing agents, and delamination agents, as shown in Fig. 11 . The etching acids have already been explained in the previous section, while the oxidizing agents include hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), molecular oxygen, cumene hydroperoxide (CHP), and tert–butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) etc. Moreover, the delamination agent usually employed to separate the stacked MXene is dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), hydrazine monohydrate (HMH), isopropyl amine (iPA) and dimethylformamide (DMF). The combined effect of all these agents will result in enhanced and controlled TiO2 formation. There are two possible ways of conducting the oxidation of Ti3C2. The first one is achieved during the etching process, while the second way is through post etching technique to enhance the quantity of TiO2. However, the oxidation in the post etching is also dependent on the etching agent used during the etching process. The post etching treated Ti3C2 oxidation is further divided into thermally treated and non-thermally treated T3C2 for the formation of TiO2 [145,149]. In another study, the oxidation of Ti3C2T x in air, liquid (water, acetone, and acetonitrile), and solid (ice and polymer) media was conducted to understand Ti3C2T x oxidation processes. The oxidation of Ti3C2T x was noticed in all the media but was found to be fastest in liquid media and slowest in solid media, including polymer [150]. Furthermore, using microwave as the annealing source, 3D MXene structure was obtained with the growth of TiO2 to develop heterojunction [103]. This reveals that not only hydrothermal but microwave can also be used to develop structured MXene with controlled growth of TiO2. From the discussion, it can be determined that the environment of different reagents is very important to enhance or reduce the oxidation process for the formation of TiO2. Apart from etching with acids, some other chemicals have been used in post etching routes for the formation of TiO2 nanoparticles during the oxidation processes. Numerous chemicals have been utilized to carry out the treatment of Ti3C2 employed for the formation of TiO2. These chemicals have various functions, such as delamination and change in functional groups of Ti3C2. For instance, Slot et al., [151] modified the surface structure of Ti3C2T x by a simple, controlled treatment with ozone at room temperature. This yielded a mildly oxidised surface, which was less oxidised as compared to hydrothermal or H2O2 treatments. The controlled oxidation with ozone resulted in rutile titania on a partially exfoliated Ti3C2T x surface. It has been seen that along with H2O2, NaOH has been found to be very helpful in carrying out the oxidation reaction for the formation of TiO2 nanoparticles. The oxidation of Ti3C2 has also been carried out in a post etching thermally treated process at different temperatures of 1000 K to 3000 K. For instance, Lofti et al., [152] studied the effects of oxidizing agents in three different environments, including dry air (oxygen molecules), wet air (oxygen and water molecules), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 molecules) for the formation of TiO2. In the study, the order of the oxidation rate in different environments was found to be in the order of H2O2 > Wet Air > Dry Air, validating the rate of formation of TiO2. Wang et al., [153] carried out a study in which after obtaining Ti3C2 through etching with HF, washing with water and subsequent drying were carried out by adding to tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) resulting in the formation of a TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. The Pillar–free TiO2/Ti3C2 with large interlayer spacing fixed by the TiO2 nanoparticles on the edge planes were obtained which fixed the Ti3C2 layers and hindered their restack. Jia et al., [154] carried out the controlled oxidation of Ti3C2 in the presence of ethanol for the formation of TiO2. The TiO2/Ti3C2 composite was prevented from restacking of the Ti3C2 nanosheets by the surface–anchored TiO2 nanoparticles and also avoided the agglomeration of TiO2 nanoparticles due to the presence of Ti3C2. In the post etching and subsequent thermal treatment, basic materials such as NaOH and KOH have also been utilized for the formation of TiO2. For instance, Li et al., [155] observed the alkalization of Ti3C2 and subsequent hydrothermal treatment that resulted in the formation of TiO2–Ti3C2. The TiO2–Ti3C2 nanoflowers formed have intimate interaction between TiO2 and Ti3C2, larger surface area, suitable light harvesting, and excellent charge separation, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity. Similarly, Quyen et al., [156] also obtained TiO2@Ti3C2 nanoflowers with three–dimensional (3D) porous frameworks from two–dimensional (2D) Ti3C2 MXene with improved photocatalytic performance through an alkalization technique by using NaOH. In other research, Xu et al., [157] obtained Ti3C2/TiO2 nanowires photocatalyst by using Ti3C2 in the presence of NaOH and H2O2. KOH has also been employed for the oxidation of Ti3C2 to form a TiO2–Ti3C2 composite. Li et al., [158] used KOH to form an urchin–Like composite of Ti3C2 MXene–derived TiO2 Nanowires with high specific surface area. Li et al., [159] studied the effect of in-situ growth of TiO2 nanosheets with preferentially exposed (001) facets from the layered Ti3C2 MXene. The TiO2 with exposed (001) surfaces is obtained through the hydrothermal oxidation of Ti3C2 with the assistance of HCl and NaBF4 for hydrogen production. The formation of TiO2 nanosheets with abundant high–activity (001) surfaces improved the photocatalytic activity towards H2 production. The obtained Ti3C2@TiO2 coupled with MoS2 composites exhibited high photocatalytic H2 evolution activity with a rate as high as 6425.297 μmol h−1 g−1. Similarly, Li et al obtained Ti3C2–TiO2 nanoflowers derived from HF–etched MXene nanosheets coupled with simultaneous oxidation and alkalization that was followed by ion exchange and calcination processes as shown in Fig. 12 (a). The formation of TiO2 in the Ti3C2–TiO2, the Ti3C2–TiO2–treated at 500 °C, TiO2 in situ growing on the surface of Ti3C2 provided intimate interaction between TiO2 and Ti3C2 resulting in high H2 and O2 evolution rates of 526 and 315 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively as shown in Fig. 12(b) among all of the samples demonstrated in Fig. 12(b–d). 5 In-situ TiO2 grown Ti3C2 MXene through thermal treatment The in–situ formation of TiO2 has found widespread application due to the control structure formation of TiO2 and very strong interaction with the parent Ti3C2 materials. The precise control of TiO2 and Ti3C2 content in the resultant TiO2/Ti3C2 composite formed through thermal treatment is strongly dependent on treatment method, temperature, type of solvent used, and atmosphere of gas present, as presented in Fig. 13 [32]. These approaches result in the in-situ formation of nanoparticles, nanosheets, nanowires or other structures (pyramid, octahedral) depending on these parameters. The in-situ growth on conductive 2D Ti3C2 generates heterogeneous interfaces that can modify native material properties. Unlike weakly–adhered mechanically mixed materials, the intimate contact facilitates the charge carrier migration, achieving efficient electron-hole separation. The synergetic effects of Ti3C2 and TiO2 endow TiO2–Ti3C2 nanocomposites with excellent properties and improved functionalities. The control over the ratio of TiO2 NPs to Ti3C2 is crucial to achieving optimized photocatalytic performance of the composite. Ti3C2T x has been treated to make hybrids by oxidizing the surface through thermal treatment, which goes through in-situ transformation [160], approach of sulfidation [160], hydrothermal treatment [161], solvothermal approach [162], deposition [161], drop casting [68], and annealing [163]. However, the commonly employed approach is hydrothermal oxidation and calcination of Ti3C2T x at a high temperature to promote the generation of TiO2 material with fine crystallinity along with the preservation of the Ti3C2Tx structure [164]. The most widely used fabrication strategies for Ti3C2 derived TiO2 photocatalysts include hydrothermal, calcination (or calcined using CO2 as oxidant), and in-situ solvothermal processes. These strategies facilitate the formation of a unique morphology of Ti3C2–TiO2 heterojunction that consists of both layered structure of Ti3C2 MXene and TiO2 particles on the MXene surface. The in-situ TiO2 formation is ascribed to the abundant Ti atom sources present in Ti3C2 MXene [165]. The formation of TiO2 from Ti3C2 MXene may create a strong heterojunction that causes the delaying of separation and migration of charged carriers. The heterojunction formation (1) Photo–induced electrons from the conduction band (CB) of TiO2 can effectively transfer and accumulate on the surface of Ti3C2, due to the large interface contact area and the quite short charge transport distance of the in-situ growth of TiO2 nanosheets on Ti3C2 allowing for the interface with minimized defects. (2) The introduction of Ti3C2 the specific surface area. The summary of the advantages and disadvantages of each thermal treatment method is demonstrated in Table 3 . Also, each method may result in improved performance through the optimization of the reactions condition. These optimized conditions are exhibited in Table 4 on the basis of each individual study. 5.1 Effect of temperature Oxidation of Ti3C2 by thermal treatment is an approach to obtaining TiO2. The oxidation of Ti-based MXenes such as Ti3C2 is popular for photocatalytic applications [160]. The in–situ conversion of Ti3C2 to TiO2 is dependent on temperature variation such as 120–220 °C for hydrothermal oxidation, calcination at 350–650 °C, flash oxidation at 1150 °C and CO2 oxidation at 500–900 °C [176]. The hydrothermal has an effect on the in–situ creation of TiO2, resulting in the formation of different facets and phases. Moreover, the effect on the colour of the composite has also been detected. The additional thermal processes such as calcination, annealing, and flash oxidation are done to improve the TiO2 formation with the proper crystal size and shape. In a study by Peng et al., [142] a hybrid of TiO2 and Ti3C2 for photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange dye was experimented with. The hydrothermal treatment of Ti3C2 at 160 °C for 12 h was known to be advantageous for the growth of (100) TiO2 facets onto Ti3C2 with TiO2/Ti3C2 heterojunctions formation. Whereas higher temperature was reported to be depletive for the Ti3C2. In another work, Ti3C2–TiO2 nano–flowers were synthesized at various temperatures of calcination to carry out oxidation of Ti3C2. It was observed that at 300 °C calcination, the Ti3C2 was present in excess, which hindered the H2 generation activity of TiO2 present on its surface, while at 500 °C the excessive TiO2 was responsible for generating electron–hole pairs rather than the metallic Ti3C2. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 14 (a) variation in nano–flowers was obtained at 300, 400 and 500 °C as nano–whiskers twisted into nano–ribbons and nano–sheets, whereas, the petals of nano–flowers were observed to be broadened with increase in temperature [155]. Kee et al., [136] calcined Ti3C2 to obtain TiO2 at 300–400 °C. The formation of TiO2 increased with increasing temperature, however, beyond treatment at 360 °C for 1 h the activity started to decline. This was attributed to the fact that the formation of TiO2 amount was maximum until 360 °C, whereas the surface area of TiO2 was high above the optimum temperature, which proved the contribution of TiO2 towards the photocatalytic activity. Recently, a study on photocatalytic dye removal was reported for TiO2/Ti3C2 hetero structure synthesized by heating H2Ti3O7/Ti3C2T x at varying temperature and time as shown in Fig. 14(b). Heating at 550 and 650 °C was recognized to be optimum for obtaining the heterojunction while, 450 °C was observed to show incomplete transformation. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 14(c and d) the nano–rods in shape of safflower were obtained, comprising of 1D TiO2 acting as a Ti source [177]. The effect of calcination temperature for Ti3C2 was studied for photocatalytic CO2 and CH4 production, attributing to the formation of sufficient TiO2 on Ti3C2 at 350, and 550 °C for photoactivity, while production activity was decreased at 650 °C which was due to the non–existence of Ti3C2 and more TiO2 formation, leading to charge carriers recombination [149]. In another study, C–doped TiO2 was obtained from Ti3C2 to form a heterojunction with g–C3N4 after calcination in air at 450 °C for 4 h which led to the complete transformation of Ti3C2 [153]. Miao et al., [163] reported photocatalytic activity of Ti3C2 with embedded TiO2 through hydrothermal treatment followed by annealing. The Ti3C2 was hydrothermally generated at 180 °C for 12 h and also by annealed at 450 °C under an N2 atmosphere. Both synthesized TiO2/Ti3C2 depicted crystalline TiO2. However, annealing treatment depicted larger particles of TiO2 as compared to only hydrothermally treated Ti3C2. Flash oxidation was reported for Ti3C2 at 1150 °C for 30 s for the formation of uniform and thin TiO2 particles, while the hydrothermal treatment in water and isothermal oxidation in CO2 at 500 °C was observed to have anatase TiO2 with unreacted Ti3C2 [160]. Peng et al. [82] investigated continuous elevated temperatures ranging from 450 to 600 °C and discovered that the weight of Ti3C2 increased slowly, owing to the oxidation of residual Ti3C2 in the interior due to O2 diffusion through newly formed TiO2. There was combustion at 600 °C due to small amount of carbon in Ti3C2 and oxidized Ti3C2. In another study, the in-situ formation of TiO2 nanosheets on the surface of Ti3C2/Ru made sure that the semiconductor and cocatalyst (TiO2/Ti3C2/Ru) were kept separate. This made charge segregation and migration work better than when Ru/TiO2/TiC2 was used [154]. Low et al., [149] observed the increasing formation rate of TiO2 nanosheets at higher temperatures but increasing number of heterojunctions at lower temperatures, and a reduction of heterojunctions at higher temperatures because of the depletion of Ti3C2. Furthermore, new diffraction lines assigned to TiO2 (anatase) were observed, suggesting the successful transformation of Ti3C2 into TiO2 as shown in Fig. 15 (a). With the increase of calcination temperature, the intensity of TiO2 gradually increased due to an increase in the TiO2 content, increase in TiO2 crystallinity, and decrease in the surface defects of the samples. The shrinkage in surface defects reduces the likelihood of electron–hole pair recombination. The intensity of the Ti3C2 was found to be decreased with increasing calcination temperature because of the transformation of Ti3C2 into the TiO2, whereas at 650 °C Ti3C2 was fully transformed into TiO2. With the change in calcination temperature showed effect on the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 towards CH4 production with maximum obtained for the sample calcined at 550 °C, as shown in Fig. 15(b). The effect of transformation of structure with change in temperature is explained in Fig. 15(c–h) which demonstrate the increase in TiO2 content with increase in temperature from 0 to 650 °C. However, the increase in the calcination temperature to 650 °C resulted in decrease in the air void spaces due to the increase in the TiO2 nanoparticles size. Zhang et al. [155] used a simple hydration method to make a hierarchical accordion-like TiO2/Ti3C2 nanohybrid, in which nano-sized TiO2 formed on the surface of the Ti3C2 and covered it evenly. The obtained TiO2/Ti3C2 nanohybrid showed an expanded interlayer spacing of ∼10.2 Å. It is evident that as the temperature was raised, the intensity of the peaks corresponding to the anatase TiO2 phase became stronger, confirming that the increase in oxidation degree of the Ti3C2 and improvement in crystallization of anatase TiO2. Miao et al., [163] observed different sizes of TiO2 particles forming at different temperatures. It was demonstrated that nanoparticles on TiO2–Ti3C2 treated at 500 °C were 3–4 times larger than TiO2–Ti3C2 at 450 °C. The gradual change in colour of Ti3C2 from black to light grey with the change in temperature range of 350–500 °C, indicating the sensitivity towards the calcination temperature. The oxidation, such as flash oxidation of Ti3C2 that is carried out for a shorter time period but at elevated temperatures, generally leads to the formation of the TiO2 anatase phase, while, oxidation at lower temperatures but for a longer time is more likely to produce the rutile phase of TiO2. It can be inferred that the oxidation temperature has a very strong effect on the formation of TiO2 quantity and resulting heterojunction formation to tune the properties of the composite. 5.2 Effect of time The in-situ conversion of Ti3C2 to TiO2 through the oxidation of Ti3C2 to TiO2 is dependent on treatment time during the hydrothermal, solvothermal, calcination or annealing treatment methods. In a study, when the treatment time was extended from 0.5 to 1 h, the peak intensity of anatase TiO2 became stronger, reflecting the increased degree of oxidation. However, longer calcination time caused the phase transformation of TiO2 from anatase to rutile [155]. In another study, Ti3C2 was obtained by H2O/O2 treatment at 60 °C. The oxidation of hybrid TiO2/Ti3C2 obtained at 60 °C contained the TiO2 at the edges of Ti3C2 achieved from oxidation of Ti atoms. At 72 h stirring and 250 to 900 °C oxidation temperature, the complete oxidation of Ti3C2 along with embedding of Ti3C2 layers by TiO2 was supported, contributing to improved photocatalytic activity. Using etching time of 24, 48, and 72 h stirred Ti3C2, depicted increased TiO2 along with prolonged stirring [178]. Similarly, the increase of annealing time has effect on TiO2/Ti3C2 formation. It was depicted that crystalline TiO2, annealing treatment, depicted larger particles of TiO2 whereas, the increase in time improved the photoactivity, but beyond 4 h annealing time, the activity declined due to an excess of O2 vacancies acting as recombination centres [163]. By controlling the hydrothermal time, the Ti3C2–TiO2 composites with different content of TiO2 can be obtained. The results obtained demonstrated that the rutile TiO2 crystals with adjustable ratios of (111) facets and (110) facets could be grown on layered Ti3C2 without any additional Ti sources. With increasing hydrothermal time, the proportion of TiO2 increases, while the proportion of Ti3C2 causes a decrease in the (111) r–TiO2/Ti3C2 composites because of the hydrothermal conversion of Ti3C2 to TiO2 [82]. Peng et al., [142] controlled the oxidation of Ti3C2 through changing the reaction duration where, the TiO2 nanosheets were homogeneously distributed around the layered Ti3C2 with enhanced accessibility to light and reactants. By improving the oxidation time for the formation of TiO2/Ti3C2 heterojunctions, the 2D Ti3C2 sheets transformed into TiO2 nanocrystals with the most active (001) facets. The intimate contact between these two phases facilitated the charge carrier’s separation of photogenerated on the (001) surfaces, resulting in the improvement of the photocatalytic activity. The activity was maximized during hydrothermal treatment for 12 h. Moreover, TiO2 has obvious light absorption only in the ultraviolet light region, while Ti3C2 shows a strong absorption capacity in both the ultraviolet and visible regions. Yang et al., [179] extended the hydrothermal treatment time, resulting in an increase in TiO2 content until the complete oxidation of Ti3C2, which resulted in a gradual decrease in the visible light adsorption capacity. This was due to a increase in the TiO2 content in the Ti3C2/TiO2 composites with an extension of reaction time. The order of photocatalytic activity was Ti3C2/TiO2–12 h > Ti3C2/TiO2–20 h > Ti3C2/TiO2–4 h, which indicated the increased TiO2 content before the first 12 h. However, beyond 12 h, the Ti3C2 content decreased, resulting in decreased photocatalytic activity. Miao et al., [163] studied the effect of annealing duration (0.5, 1, 2, and 4 h) carried out to modulate the oxygen vacancies in TiO2 to investigate its role in the photocatalytic performance of TiO2/Ti3C2, respectively. After the hydrothermal oxidation process, TiO2 nanoparticles were distributed on the surface and between the Ti3C2 sheets to contribute to effective prevention of the accumulation of sheets and an increase to the specific surface area of material. It was determined that the annealing for 2 h resulted in optimum quantity of oxygen vacancies, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity. It can be determined that heating time has a very strong effect on the in-situ growth of TiO2 on the Ti3C2 surface. Optimized time selection is important as further increase may further worsen the properties of the composite such as the reduced quantity of Ti3C2 high increase in the quantity of oxygen vacancies resulting photocatalytic activity. Liu et al [154] studied the effect of hydrothermal treatment on time and found that with increasing hydrothermal reaction time, the TiO2 content increased, resulting in complete conversion after 36 h. The maximum H2 evolution rate was obtained for TiO2 − Ti3C2/Ru when treated for 20 h with a yield rate of 235.3 μmol g−1 h−1. However, further increased in the hydrothermal reaction time resulted in a decreased H2 production as shown in Fig. 15(i). The decrease in H2 production was due to the disappearance of conducting Ti3C2. The formation of TiO2 over Ti3C2 was confirmed through SEM images given in Fig. 15 (j–m) that showed the increase of TiO2 content with an increase in hydrothermal treatment time. 5.3 Effect of environment The oxidation of Ti3C2 during the thermal treatment is highly dependent on the treatment conditions, which are responsible for altering the structural properties [180]. The change in the environment during the oxidation of Ti3C2 is very crucial as it may affect the in-situ formation of TiO2. The effect of change in environment may include the change of solvent, gases on the surface of the solvent or etching agent, intercalating agent, or microwave heating method. Responsible for altering the structural properties the oxidation causes the anatase TiO2 to grow on its flake edges and basal planes, however the choice of solvent is known to influence the structure of formed TiO2 as Ti3C2/TiO2 hybrid, ranging from the simplest layered structures to complex structures [180]. Liu et al [89], studied the Ti3C2@TiO2 for photocatalytic activity and reported in-situ transformation of Ti3C2 into TiO2 by air–calcination in NaOH solution at a lower temperature. As depicted in Fig. 16 (a), the use of deionized water and NaOH as a solvent yielded nanoparticles and nanowires of TiO2, respectively, whereas, the increase in molar concentration of NaOH from 1 M to 3 M resulted in the formation nanowires wrapped into Ti3C2. In case of water, only the Ti on the surface was oxidized to TiO2 nanoparticles [181]. Peng et al., [82] studied the effect of NH4F solvent on the formation of TiO2, used as a morphology directing agent. It can be seen in Fig. 16(b) at low concentration of NH4F, (110) facets of rutile TiO2 phase were produced whereas, the increase in reagent concentration led to the formation of (111) facet as indicated in Fig. 16(c) [82]. It indicated that the low energy rutile (110) facets vanished gradually with the increasing quantity of NH4F, and TiO2 octahedrons with almost complete (111) facets were prepared at 0.045 M NH4F. During this process, the proportion of (111) facets increased from 24% to more than 90%, estimated by the geometry of TiO2 particles. The presence of NH4F showed a very strong effect on the formation of TiO2. The Ti3C2/Ti3+–TiO2 composites synthesized from Ti3C2 by using H2O2 as an oxidizing agent supported the formation of self–doped mosaic structured particles of TiO2 [182]. Thermal treatment at 200 °C in the presence of ethanol was carried out to get TiO2 growth over Ti3C2 leading to a photocatalyst with improved integrity of structure [154]. Li ae al., [155] studied the formation of Ti3C2–TiO2 nano–flowers from simultaneous oxidation and alkalization of Ti3C2 under hydrothermal treatment with NaOH and H2O2. These nano–flowers were superior in photocatalytic H2 generating activity based on the ability to carry out HER and ORR together as well as offered better optical properties and enlarged surface area. Zou et al., [183] obtained the growth of the lattice plane by modifying the solvents under the –F containing conditions. Urchin–like 2D rutile TiO2–C nanomaterial–with a high amount of (110) facets by in situ solvothermal alcoholysis of MXene in FeCl3 solution was obtained as shown in Fig. 16(d and e). The urchin–like rutile TiO2–C was composed of rutile TiO2 nanorods and layered C/TiC, in which the introduction of Fe (III) ions transformed the intermediate product of anatase TiO2–C into urchin like TiO2. The MXene was found to be stable in the isopropyl alcohol (IPA) solution added to strengthen the stabilization effect associated with –F adsorption on the surface. However, the addition of ethylene glycol resulted in the formation of some new peaks of anatase TiO2 (A–TiO2). It was revealed that the alcohol decomposition of MXene took place and the surface groups of Ti–OH or Ti–F changed to Ti–O groups (TiO2). The presence of gases present on the surface of the solvent may affect the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite performance. In this regard, an increased annealing duration and continuous flow of N2 were observed to sweep away the generated O2, which gradually reduced the oxygen content and resulted in an increased concentration of oxygen vacancies [163]. Yuan et al [164], reported the HF etching of Ti3AlC2 into Ti3C2 and the formation of 2D carbon/TiO2 by rapid oxidation of Ti3C2 at elevated temperature under CO2 environment, which oxidized the C atoms into layered C and Ti atoms to TiO2. The in-situ investigation of the CO2 gas environment through hydrothermal treatment, resulted in hybrid structures of nanocrystalline anatase with amorphous carbon at significantly lower temperatures [160]. The maximum hydrogen product rate achieved for 2D–layered C/TiO2 was found to be 24.04 µmol h−1, which is about 89 times higher than that of pure TiO2 as shown in Fig. 16(f). The sulphur doped TiO2 and C substrate obtained from Ti3C2 was synthesized by carrying out mild oxidation treatment in CO2 as well as in air as shown in Fig. 16(g). The air oxidation yielded uniform and exposed particles of TiO2 of 50 nm size with overall structural stability, whereas the CO2 oxidation led to excessive production of carbon (C) which hindered light penetration during photocatalytic H2 generation [184]. The H2 generation rate under visible light irradiation reached up to 333 µmol g−1 h−1 due to the synergic effect of porous carbon substrate and S doping. In another work, air calcination was carried out for Ti3C2 with coupled TiO2 doped C and g–C3N4. The simple calcination led to complete oxidation of Ti3C2 into C/TiO2 offering improved coupling of heterojunction and larger surface area for photocatalytic H2 evolution however, the typical structural nature of Ti3C2 was changed at higher calcination temperature [153]. The microwave assisted thermal treatment was explored to be cost effective and simple method to form TiO2/Ti3C2 nanocomposite structure as it provided a huge specific surface area and an excellent TiO2 absorption and optoelectronic properties [132]. 6 Applications of Ti3C2 MXene 6.1 Photocatalytic hydrogen production The application of MXenes in energy storage, supercapacitors, and batteries [185] as well as towards photocatalytic processes is mainly based on their electronic properties, metal like conductive properties, hydrophilic nature and structural feasibility [186]. A variety of photocatalytic semiconductor materials are available, but their low visible light activity and charge recombination hinder their practical application. MXene 2D photocatalyst materials, especially Ti3C2, are prominent for their efficient light harvesting and electron trapping [187]. Moreover, in comparison to other semiconductors, the less Fermi level of MXene makes them an ideal co–catalyst for photocatalytic reactions [114]. In this context, many studies investigated the utilization of Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst with widely used binary semiconductors in photocatalysis such as Ti3C2/ZnS [188], Ti3C2/CdS [189] and Ti3C2/g–C3N4 [190], Ti3C2/TiO2 [165] to overcome their limitations of wide band gap and charge carriers recombination. Due to their exceptional properties, the Ti3C2 MXene based photocatalysts have found widespread application in the field of photocatalytic H2 production. The studies of the MXene based H2 production photoactivity, selectivity, and stability have been summarized in Table 5 . Generally, by introducing Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst with a semiconductor, a Schottky junction is formed, which will act to promote separation of electron hole pairs. For instance, the formation of 2D/2D ultrathin Ti3C2/SnNb2O6 nanocomposite for photocatalytic degradation due to the formation of Schottky barrier as the CB position of SnNb2O6 showed more negative as compared to the lower fermi level of Ti3C2, thus electrons were supported to move from SnNb2O6 to Ti3C2, leading to inhibition of charge recombination [191]. Furthermore, the following properties of Ti3C2 make them ideal for photocatalytic applicate ions: 1) Enlarged specific surface area; 2) Functional group as terminations, creating a strong connection through formation of Schottky barrier with other photocatalyst materials; 3) Improved charge separation for inhibition of charge carrier’s recombination; 4) Metal like conductivity for boosted charge mobility and charge separation; 5) The metal sites on the surface creates boosted active reactivity in comparison to other C based photocatalysts [25,26,61]. Recently, a study reported the hydrogen generation of 11182.4 μmol g−1 h−1 by using CdLa2S4/Ti3C2 nanocomposites where, CdLa2S4 was grown on Ti3C2 sheets. The excellent H2 generation and stability up to six cycles can be attributed to the metallic conductivity of Ti3C2, which aided charge separation. Also, Ti3C2 was recognized as an earth–abundant MXene for the construction of cost effective and efficient photocatalysts for energy applications [72]. Photocatalysts forming a heterojunction having an appropriate dimensionality and a good interfacial contact are highly efficient for solar to energy conversion. In this regard, protonated g–C3N4 was studied in a face-to-face contact with Ti3C2 to form of Schottky barrier for charge transfer, attributing it to the excellent conductivity of MXene material for capturing electrons from g–C3N4 and providing them with active sites for reaction [192]. In another work, Wang et al., achieved water splitting through the fine dispersion of physicochemical properties of Ti3C2T x with TiO2. The 2D Ti3C2T x provides a good platform for TiO2 NPs, leading to good interfacial contact. Moreover, the optical property was tuned by controlling the loading of Ti3C2T x i.e., 5 wt% [193]. Currently, overall water splitting has been reported by Schottky barrier formation of ultrathin BiVO4 and nanosheets of Ti3C2. Generally, BiVO4 is known for its visible light activity for O2 production, but it lacks the ability for H2 generation as it constitutes a more positive CB compared to water reduction potential, making it inactive for overall water splitting. However, in heterojunction with Ti3C2, the generated electrons were able to transfer to MXene cocatalyst as the Fermi levels of Ti3C2 and BiVO4 were 0.38 eV and –0.69 eV, respectively while they have work function of 45.92 eV and 0.67 eV, respectively, as demonstrated in Fig. 17 (a and b). The electrons transferred to MXene carried out H2 evolution while, the holes left behind were responsible for carrying out O2 evolution, as shown in Fig. 17(c and d) [15]. In another work, a novel 2D/1D photocatalyst of Ti3C2/TiO2 was studied for H2 production that was increased than the H2 generated by nanofibers of TiO2 and was associated with the interfacial contact between the MXene cocatalyst and semiconductor [194]. The efficiency of the photocatalytic system was associated with the provision of increased sites for reaction, good light reflection, and reduced distance charge carrier diffusion [155]. The HER activity is related to the charge state of O atoms on the surface, which in turn is affected by the coverage of OH. The O terminations could regulate the surface electronic properties and enhance the HER performance. However, the presence of –F terminal group may reduce the performance towards HER activity [195]. 6.2 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction Photocatalytic CO2 reduction is considered to have a vital role in overcoming energy and environmental issues by not only reducing CO2 but is also providing energy. Since, 1970, when Halmann and Inoue et al., [202] pioneered CO2 conversion, many studies have been carried out by using various semiconductors like GaN, g–C3N4, WO3, TiO2, Fe2O3 and ZnO for the conversion of CO2 into HCOOH, CO, CH4, CH3OH and HCHO [203–208]. The use of Ti3C2 in CO2 reduction to fuels is a noble metal free photocatalytic reaction due to its excellent conductivity, good optical features, unique structure and surface functional groups. The surface of Ti3C2 having –OH functional groups as terminations offers the advantage of increased basic sites, making the CO2 molecules of acidic nature to be adsorbed effectively on its surface for reaction. Moreover, the Ti3C2 based photocatalysts also show inhibition of charge carriers and good redox capability [209,210]. Due to these exceptional properties, Ti3C2 MXene based photocatalysts have found widespread applications in the field of photolytic reduction CO2. The advancements in the field of CO2 reduction have been discussed in Table 6 . In this context, Ti3C2 QDs were decorated onto TiO2/g–C3N4 core–shell and they achieved photocatalytic CO2 reduction into CO and CH4. A Step scheme and Schottky junction were formed for TiO2/g–C3N4 and Ti3C2 QDs/g–C3N4, respectively, for efficient charge separation, charge transport and redox reactions. Also, TiO2/g–C3N4 offered a wide interfacial contact and also provided a short pathway for migration of electrons. Ti3C2 acted as an electron sink but, apart from the work, it also carried out the modification of edges of Ti3C2 QDs with amine groups, which further provided the additional feature of extra actives sites [17]. In another work, halide perovskite FAPbBr3 QDs showing a high rate of charge recombination were used to from Schottky junction with Ti3C2 for CO2 reduction by photocatalysis. The role of Ti3C2 was to supply active sites for catalytic reaction and also to inhibit charge recombination by acting as a sink for electrons. The nanocomposite showed an electron consumption rate of 717.18 μmol g–1 h−1 which was 2.08 times increased as compared to the pure halide perovskite with extraordinary stability [211]. Low et al., studied the in-situ growth of TiO2 nanoparticles onto Ti3C2 which led to efficient CO2 reduction to CH4, which was 3.7 times more efficient than commercial TiO2 (P25). The photocatalytic activity was highest for sample calcined at 550 °C due to the presence of increase amount of TiO2 on the surface of Ti3C2 however, the photoactivity declined above this temperature and was 2.8 folds lower than Ti3C2 calcined at 550 °C. The decline in activity was associated with excess growth of TiO2, causing charge carrier recombination and the reduced surface area was also another contributor to reduced activity. At 550 °C, the surface area was enhanced and sufficient to provide active sites for the adsorption of CO2 molecules. Apart from this, MXene played a vital role in enhancing the light absorption of the composite by photothermal effect due to its dark colour while, the nanocomposite promoted efficient charge separation [149]. Similarly, Shen et al., proposed a CeO2/Ti3C2–MXene hybrid for improved photocatalytic CO2 into CO, attributing it to the electric filed developed on the interface of the semiconductor and cocatalyst contact which contributed to efficient charge separation. The highest rate of CO generation was achieved with a 3% loading of Ti3C2 with CeO2 i.e., 29.7 µmol m−2 h−1 and the CO generated was 1.5 folds increased than pristine CeO2 [212]. Similarly, loading the surface–alkalinized Ti3C2 MXene onto ZnO through facile electrostatic self–assembly strategy demonstrated extraordinarily enhanced generation rates of CO (30.30 μmol g−1 h−1) and CH4 (20.33 μmol g−1 h−1) that were nearly 7 and 35–times higher as compared to pristine ZnO, respectively. The enhancement was attributed to the improved photoinduced charge separation and transfer of and the adsorption/activation of CO2 molecules [206]. The construction of 2D/2D heterojunction between MXenes and 2D semiconductors can establish robust interface contact between cocatalyst and photocatalyst. For instance, a 2D/2D nanocomposite was synthesized by urea with Ti3C2, forming a Ti3C2/g–C3N4 heterojunction. Urea acted as a precursor for the synthesis of g–C3N4 and also exfoliated the Ti3C2 into nanosheets. 5.19 μmol h−1 g−1 and 0.044 μmol h−1 g−1 CO and CH4 were generated from CO2 reduction whereas, Ti3C2/g–C3N4 generated 8.1 folds increased overall CO2 reduction in comparison to pure g–C3N4. The heterojunction promoted charge separation as the electrons were transferred from g–C3N4 to Ti3C2 as discussed in Fig. 17(e). Moreover, composites demonstrate a strong chemisorption effect, which augments the CO2 adsorption capacity and is conducive to the activation of CO2 [113]. Similarly, Yang et al [213] fabricated the g–C3N4/TiO2/C (SL–EAC) hybrid of ultrathin g–C3N4 on monolayered Ti3C2T x that resulted in the formation of TiO2/C, due to the calcination of g–C3N4/Ti3C2T x attained through electrostatic self–assembly. The Van der Waals force between protonated g–C3N4 and Ti3C2T x monolayer with negative charge empowered a strong 2D/2D interaction between them. The composite formed S–scheme electrons transfer that did the reduction of CO2 on SL–EAC with 2.88– and 5.82–folds production of CO and CH4 respectively, as compared to pristine g–C3N4. Similarly, 2D/2D heterojunction of ultrathin Ti3C2/Bi2WO6nanosheets was synthesized in situ growth of Bi2WO6ultrathin nanosheets on the surface of these Ti3C2 ultrathin nanosheets that exhibited short charge transport distance and a large interfacial area with outstanding bulk–to–surface and interfacial charge transfer capabilities. Also, the enhanced pore structure and specific surface area endowed the Ti3C2/Bi2WO6 composite with an increased CO2 adsorption capacity. The maximum production of CH4 and CH3OH attained on the Ti3C2/Bi2WO6 nanocomposite was 4.6 fold higher as compared to pristine Bi2WO6 nanosheets [214]. 6.3 Photo-electrocatalytic water splitting Photoelectrochemical water splitting is another approach of energy issues through the generation of either H2 from water or methanol fuel from CO2. At first, an n-type anode of TiO2 was employed to carry out water oxidation under a photoelectrochemical process, after which investigations were carried out to explore efficient photocatalysts to act as an anode and cathode in a photoelectrochemical cell [220]. The photoelectrochemical process consists of reduction and oxidation reactions which are achieved by a photoactive cathode of p-type semiconductor material and a photoactive anode of n-type semiconductor. Among various photocatalyst semiconductors, most of the photocatalysts show limitations in kinetics, especially towards the generation of O2 as it involves the movement of complicated ions. In this regard, RuO2, Pt, and IrO2 are utilized to carry out the reaction, but their use is also limited based on their high cost and their storing [44]. MXenes are considered as an electrocatalyst for O2 and H2 evolution due to their larger surface areas, surface hydrophilic nature, and surface functional groups. The Ti3C2 MXene has been as prospect material for photoelectrochemical water splitting that has been discussed in Table 7 . In this context, Sreedhar et al., studied the photoelectrochemical water splitting by anchoring of Ti3C2 MXene onto flaked ZnO. The varying positions of Ti3C2 in the nanocomposite were studied to affect the ability to separate charge carriers. The highest yield of product in the form of H2 was achieved when the MXene was anchored onto ZnO by growing Ti3C2 (002) reflection along with ZnO (002) (ZnO/Ti3C2) because of the electron trapping ability of Ti3C2 MXene for charge separation rather than placing it under the surface of ZnO flakes (Ti3C2/ZnO). As depicted in Fig. 17(f), in both position of Ti3C2, electrons are collected from ZnO to Ti3C2 but in case of ZnO/Ti3C2, the holes in VB of ZnO took part in O2 generation at counter electrode while, in the case of Ti3C2/ZnO, the working electrode was involved. Moreover, it also prompted hydrophilicity as the angle of ZnO/Ti3C2 was 42° with water in comparison to 56° for Ti3C2/ZnO [221]. In another study, Ti3C2 underwent modification with cations before the formation of a nanocomposite with MoS2 to form MoS2 − Ti3C2 electrocatalyst. The MoS2 was found to be grown along the (002) crystal plane and has an edge–orientation with a thickness of a few layers, leading to the stabilization of MXene against oxidation along with the provision of reaction sites, migration of electrons, and efficient kinetics [179]. Photoelectrochemical water splitting was also studied for TiO2/Ti3C2 where, FTO substrate having a coating of TiO2 was deposited by Ti3C2 to form a photoanode while Pt was considered as a counter electrode. The interfacial contact of TiO2 and Ti3C2 led to the generation of Ti3+ at the contact and were capable of extracting electrons. The charge carriers recombination was inhibited as Ti3C2 acted as a hole trapping medium, which proves the role of MXene in the oxidation reaction [68]. Likewise, another nanocomposite having a seamless coat of 2D cobalt 1,4– benzenedicarboxylate (CoBDC) MOF onto electronegative Ti3C2T x was studied for electrocatalytic O2 evolution from alkali solution. The interfacial contact offered vigorous migration of charges and ions for the electrocatalysis. This is attributed to Ti3C2T x which speeded up the kinetics of reactions as well as its hydrophilic nature stopped the accumulation of porous MOF and at the same time provided route for the electrolyte to travel to the surface of photocatalysts [222]. Yu et al [223] hybridized La–doped NiFe–layered double hydroxides (NiFe–LDH) 2D nanosheets on 3D vertically aligned MXene nanosheets on nickel foam (NF) substrates (NiFeLa–LDH/v–MXene/NF) for water splitting to generate O2 and H2 electrochemically. The electrocatalytic activity of the synthesized NiFeLa–LDH/v–MXene/NF was enhanced due to the synergistic effect of robust electronic interaction amongst plentiful metal centres and vertically aligned porous MXene with improved active surface area, resulting in faster reaction kinetics and better adsorption of water and dissociation. The NiFeLa–LDH/v–MXene/NF demonstrated significantly decreased overpotentials of 255 and 233 mV for OER and HER activities, respectively, along with excellent stability. 6.4 Photoelectrocatalytic CO2 reduction The photoelectrochemical (PEC) reduction of CO2 is a process that can combine the qualities of both photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, boosting the magnificent talent for CO2 reduction with excellent efficiency and outstanding selectivity. Since Halmann [202] first conducted the photoelectrochemical reduction of CO2 into methanoic acid over a GaP catalyst, the improvement of extremely effective catalysts for CO2 reduction has obtained widespread consideration. Many attempts have been made to enhance the photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction activity and product selectivity by exploring novel photoelectrode materials, such as oxides, nitrides, sulfides, LDHs, MOFs, and inorganic perovskite. However, the efficiency is still low and, in this scenario, MXene based photoelectrodes have been employed to enhance the efficiency through photoelectrochemical conversion. The summary of the recent progress for Ti3C2 based semiconductors has been discussed in Table 8 . For instance, by employing MXene material, a photocathode was formed by fabricating a layered hybrid heterojunction through in-situ grown TiO2 on 2D titanium carbide (Ti3C2) nanosheets (TiO2/Ti3C2) for the CO2 conversion. The obtained TiO2/Ti3C2 heterojunction was functionalized with imine ligands and Pd nanoparticles on Fluorine–doped tin oxide (FTO) glass plate to form (Pd/N–TiO2/Ti3C2/FTO) to enhance efficiency. The presence of Pd nanoparticles and imine ligand mimicked the role of NADP and CO2 absorber in the Calvin cycle of plant photosynthesis. The schematic illustration of the synthesis of the Pd/N–TiO2/Ti3C2/FTO electrode is demonstrated in Fig. 18 (a). The layered TiO2/Ti3C2 heterojunction materials showed a a moderate bandgap of 2.1 eV that contributed to visible light absorption. In the photoelectrochemical cell of Pd/N–TiO2/Ti3C2||BiVO4 the hydrocarbons such as formate, methanol and ethanol were produced. The evolution rate of the total hydrocarbons was observed to be 73.6 μM cm−2 h−1 (36.8 mM h−1 g−1). Also, H2 gas can be produced when the external voltage is offered by Si solar cells as low as − 0.4 V, owing to the excellent activity of the heterojunction structure [143]. The Ti3C2 can be employed as work material to form an “M−scheme” heterojunction as a CO2 reduction agent based on dual interfacial heterojunction through in situ growth of TiO2 and hybridizing with CeO2. For instance, in a study, an “M−scheme” CeO2/Ti3C2/TiO2 (CTT) photocatalyst was employed for CO2 reduction. The dual heterojunction photocatalyst is fabricated by annealing CeO2/Ti3C2 to form anatase TiO2 in situ. The CTT photocatalyst is comprised of CeO2/Ti3C2 and TiO2/Ti3C2 that substantially enhanced the charge carrier transfer resulting in enhanced photoelectric performance with the help of M−scheme electrons transfer as demonstrated in Fig. 18(b). The Ti3C2 exhibited a metallic property in the CTT composite, which acted as a platform to collect the transferred electrons and assisted in the conversion of H2 molecules to H+. The reaction between H+ and CO on Ti3C2 enhanced the selectivity of CH4. The selectivity obtained for CO2 to CH4 was enhanced up to the level of 70.68% at room temperature. This work creates a pathway to develop effectively and selectively with help of Ti3C2 [232]. In a similar way, TiO2 was generated in through a facile hydrothermal oxidation treatment of Ti3CN resulting the formation of two–2D heterojunctions of TiO2@Ti3CN that were used as photocathodes for CO2 reduction. The in situ grown TiO2/Ti3CN heterojunctions demonstrated outstanding light absorption with increased specific surface area, rich in Ti3+ species and oxygen vacancies, advantageous for the photogeneration and transfer of electron–hole pairs. The photo electrocatalysis cell demonstrated in Fig. 18(c) with Pd@TiO2/Ti3CN||SCE||BiVO4 resulted in the formation of formate, methanol and ethanol as the major products, with the total maximum formation rate of 45.6 μM cm–2 h−1 under optimal conditions [233]. Similarly, the fabrication of Ti3C2/g–C3N4 (TCCN) heterojunctions by in situ thermal treatment can also be employed for photoelectrochemical CO2 reduction. The heterojunctions formed demonstrated narrow band gaps of around (2.3–2.6 eV) with abundant Ti3+ species, beneficial for the absorption of solar light and efficient electron and hole separation. The Ti3+ species suppressed the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes in the formed heterojunctions. Also, the existence of plentiful pyri–N species in the TCCN heterojunctions improved CO2 molecule adsorption, beneficial for CO2 reduction. The deposition of Pd metal particles hastened the charge carrier’s transfer. In a system of two–electrone of M−TCCN‖BiVO4, the total generation rate of methanol and formate was as high as 50.2 μM cm−2 h−1 (25.1 mM h−1 g−1) that was tenfold higher as compared to pristine g–C3N4. These TCCN heterojunctions showed excellent PEC performance and stability which were beneficial for solar–to–fuel engineering field [234]. Many efforts have been made to enhance the generation, charge separation, and transfer for photoelectrocatalytic CO2 reduction. In this scenario, a novel nanocomposite was fabricated by the in–situ growth of CsPbBr3 perovskite nanocrystals on 2D Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets. Proficient charge transfer between CsPbBr3 NCs and Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets was signified by substantial photoluminescence (PL) reduction and shorter PL decay lifetimes as compared to pristine CsPbBr3 NCs. The as-obtained CsPbBr3/Ti3C2T x nanocomposites demonstrated increased photocurrent generation in visible light and X-ray irradiations, demonstrating to the prospective application of these heterostructure for photoelectric generation as demonstrated in Fig. 18(d and e). The efficient charge transfer in CsPbBr3/Ti3C2T x nanocomposite signifies an active photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO and CH4 [216]. Apart from the photoelectrochemical reduction, the MXene based photocatalysts have been tested separately in electrochemical workstations along to analyse the photoelectrochemical performance. For instance, Zen et al observed that the incorporation of Ti3C2 quantum dots (QD) onto Cu2O nanowires (NWs) through a self–assembly strategy resulted in an enhancement of photocurrent density. The obtained Ti3C2 QDs/Cu2O NWs/Cu composite showed the highest among the three heterostructures demonstrated in Fig. 18(f) that was attributed to the enhanced light absorption capability, charge separation, and transport assisted by Ti3C2 QDs. The photostability of Ti3C2 QDs/Cu2O NWs/Cu was also the maximum in comparison to other heterostructures demonstrated in Fig. 18(g) [73]. Similarly, the photoelectrochemical tests have been used to analyze the CO2 photoreduction performance of 3D hierarchical CoCo–LDH/Ti3C2T x nanosheets (Co–Co LDH/TNS) synthesized through in-situ MOF–derived strategy. The PL spectescopy was used to study the separation and recombination of the photogenerated charge that showed that the intensity of PL signal was reduced due to the addition of TNS into CoCo–LDH as demonstrated in Fig. 18(h). On the other hand, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed to analyse the electrons transport ability. From Fig. 18(i), it is clear that Co–Co LDH/TNS composite displayed a smaller semicircle indicating a lower electron–transfer resistance for the nanocomposite allowing rapid transport and separation of interface charge, conducive for CO2 photoreduction [215]. Similarly, Yang et al crosschecked the photoelectrochemical performance of 2D/2D Ti3C2 MXene/g–C3N4 nanosheets heterojunction for highly efficient CO2 reduction by employing PL, EIS and transient photocurrent response (TPR) techniques that validated the enhancement in the performance of CO2 reduction by employing Ti3C2 MXene based Ti3C2 MXene/g–C3N4 hybrid proving the enhancement in enhancement in charge separation and transport [113]. Also, Cao et al [214] used the photoelectrochemical test to study the charge transfer capability for the reduction of CO2. The EIS Nyquist plots showed that the Ti3C2/Bi2WO6 displayed a smaller semicircle radius as compared to Bi2WO6, implying lower charge transfer resistance and efficient charge transfer across the interfacial contact surface. The TPR of Ti3C2/Bi2WO6 showed enhanced photocurrent intensity than Bi2WO6 confirming better charge transfer ability. 7 Conclusions and future perspective 7.1 Conclusions Ti3C2 MXene is recognized as a developing two–dimensional material, acting as a non–noble metal based cocatalyst for photocatalytic applications. The synthesis of Ti3C2 by etching from MAX is strongly dependent on type and concentration of etching agent, reaction time, intercalation agents, and synthesis conditions, resulting in modified properties such as conducting and semiconducting properties, termination groups, defect morphology, and structure of Ti3C2 MXene. They show flexibility in their structure to be transformed into ultrathin 2D single nanosheets and 0D quantum dots (QDs), leading to the possibility of designed multi–functional photocatalysts. The photoactivity is attributed to their heterojunction and Schottky interface formation as well as based on their ability to act as a cocatalyst. Furthermore, the efficiency of the photosystem incorporated by Ti3C2 as a cocatalyst can further be enhanced by modifying its morphological, compositional properties. The following properties play a vital role for making Ti3C2 MXene applicable towards photocatalytic applications towards energy production: 1. The metallic nature of Ti3C2 makes them excellent for electrical conductivity, while the electronic properties of MXenes can be tuned by simply tuning the terminations in the form of functional groups, adjustment in morphological features and by composite formation. 2. Different concentrations of etching agents result in different morphology and interlayer spacing. The higher concentration decrease time for the selective removal of Al from MAX, expand the interlayer spacing, promote formation of accordion–like structure and defects. The etching time is dependent on the concentration of etchant. To lessen the etching time, concentration of etchant should be increased or mechanical ultrasonication can be employed. 3. The low Fermi level of MXene makes them an ideal co–catalyst for photocatalytic reactions to form Schottky barrier with other semiconductors to promote charge separation and inhibit charge recombination 4. Enlarged specific surface area and presence of metal sites their surface make them offer boosted active reactivity in comparison to other C based photocatalysts. 5. Ti3C2 offer highly hydrophilic property, induced due to the presence of terminational functional groups on its surface. 6. The delamination of MXene sheets by using an intercalant into a single layer imparted an exceptional advantage over their multilayer counterpart. The intercalant generates more interlayer spacing and offers least oxidation of Ti3C2 for improved conductivity and optical ability. 7. The oxidation of Ti3C2 is dependent on several factors, including temperature, the chance of exposure to O2, structural defects in the as–synthesized Ti3C2 and the functional groups on the surface that may affect the in-situ formation of TiO2. 8. With appropriate selection of type of etching agent, etchant concentration, time of oxidation, TiO2 with certain phase, composition and morphology can be obtained. Selection of an appropriate acid with higher concentration having a low pH leads to stronger oxidation of Ti3C2 into TiO2. Also, as the etching time of Ti3C2 with etchant increase until an optimum limit, the interlayer distances increase for more exposure of oxidation surface and defects are also formed to promote oxidation of Ti into TiO2. The selectivity of rutile and anatase TiO2 formation is dependent on the solid or liquid environment of etching. 9. In the thermal treatment methods, the selection of type of treatment, time and temperature should be performed to promote generation of TiO2 material with fine crystallinity along with the preservation of the Ti3C2T x structure and its intimate contact with obtained TiO2. The oxidation at elevated temperatures generally leads to the formation of TiO2 anatase phase while, oxidation under lower temperature but for longer time is more likely to produce rutile phase of TiO2 along with longer calcination time causing the phase transformation of TiO2 from anatase to rutile. 7.2 Future perspectives In comparison to 2D graphene, the 2D MXene materials are at the initial stages of development. The following challenges and prospects exist in MXene Ti3C2 photocatalyst material for photocatalytic applications: 1. New approaches for the synthesis of photo–efficient Ti3C2 MXene with improved and large lateral dimensions and termination groups are necessary. 2. Exploration of theoretical calculations and experimental results are highly desired to synthesize Ti3C2 without functional groups as terminations. Challenges in the synthesis of Ti3C2 having a single functional group as surface termination still persist. In this regard, chemical vapor deposition and physical methods are encouraged to be employed for the synthesis of termination free Ti3C2. 3. As Ti3C2 MXene is known for insignificant semiconducting properties thus, understanding of fundamental properties of intercalated Ti3C2 is an important along with the underlying mechanisms is important to be explored for implementing them in photocatalytic applications. 4. New composites with Ti3C2 MXene as a cocatalyst can be designed and employed in solar to energy conversion mainly after exploration of the fundamental properties of Ti3C2 towards electrocatalysis and catalysis. 5. The enhancement in the electrochemical properties can be obtained through crystal surface regulation, morphology and size regulation, defect regulation, selection of proper etching strategy and intercalant, reaction temperature and acid concentration. 6. Ti3C2 MXene is outstanding conducting materials in the composites formed that demonstrate robust interfacial coupling with conjugate materials and fast charge transfer kinetics that can efficiently improve the electrochemical properties of hybrid composites. 7. The limitation of instability of Ti3C2 MXene by oxidation in air and water still remains an unsolved challenge. Presently, sub–zero temperatures are used for the storage of Ti3C2 MXene based materials but, are not practically sound thus, more appropriate approaches for avoiding oxidation of its surface need to be designed. 8. The employment of Ti3C2 MXene can replace the conductor materials such as rGO and noble metals that have been considered as very expensive materials. This replacement may result in the employment of very cheap material as compared to expensive materials resulting in economical prospective material. Chem. A 6 (2018) 15213–15220. Muhammad Tahir is currently working as Assistant Professor at Chemical and Petroleum Engineering Department, United Arab Emirates University. He has been working in different research areas such as clean energy production, photocatalysis, water treatment, CO2 conversion and water splitting. He is a recipient of the several national and international awards and working with journals such as Energy and Environmental Materials, and Frontier in Energy Research and Molecules. Azmat Ali Khan received his B.Sc (2009) in Chemical Engineering from University of Engineering and Technology, Peshawar, Pakistan, MS (2013) in Petroleum Engineering from Politecnico di Torino, Italy and PhD (2022) in Chemical Engineering from University Technology Malaysia (UTM) under supervison of Dr. Muhammad Tahir. He is currently working as Assistant Professor at the Department of Chemical Engineering, Baluchistan University of Information Technology, Engineering and Management Sciences (BUITEMS), Quetta, Pakistan. The author research areas are solar energy conversion and photocatalysis. Sehar Tasleem did her PhD in Chemical Engineering from University Technology Malaysia (UTM) under the supervision of Dr. Muhammad Tahir. Dr. Sehar research interest involves the synthesis of perovskites materials and their composite for photocatalytic hydrogen production. She has published research articles in high impact journals. Rehan Mansoor is a faculty member as Lecturer at Department of Petroleum Engineering, Balochistan University of Information Technology & Engineering (BUITEMS), Pakistan. He obtained his Bachelor of Engineering degree from University of Engineering & Technology Lahore (Pakistan). Recently, he completed his Masters in Petroleum Engineering from University Technology Malaysia. His research focused on photocatalytic Natural gas conversion to renewable fuels and Chemically Enhanced CO2 sequestration and storage (CCUS). Areen Sherryna received her bachelor’s degree in Chemical Engineering from University Technology Malaysia (UTM) in 2020. She is currently pursuing a PhD degree in Chemical Engineering under the supervision of Dr. Muhammad Tahir. Her research interest includes the design and fabrication of nanomaterials for solar hydrogen production. Beenish Tahir received her MSc and PhD degrees in Chemical Engineering from University Technology Malaysia (UTM) in 2016 and 2019, respectively. She is working as a postdoctoral at United Arab Emirates University, UAE. Her research work involves reactor design, photocatalysis, CO2 reduction, dry reforming of methane and water splitting for hydrogen production.

coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic solar to energy conversion is considered an attractive approach for overcoming energy crises and environmental concerns. Recently, titanium carbide (Ti3C2) MXenes have been recognized as promising cocatalysts based on their metallic conductivity, excessive active reaction sites, and enlarged surface area. The current review focuses on the properties and applications of Ti3C2 MXenes useful in the field of photocatalysis. More specifically, surface modification of Ti3C2 MXenes by varying synthesis parameters to get pure materials and also composites with the role of functional groups towards solar energy conversion applications is highlighted in this review. The effect of etching and oxidizing pathways to get an efficient cocatalyst has been discussed in detail. Considering the significant effect of parameters, optimum synthesis conditions such as etchant type, concentration, time and type of intercalant in both the Ti3C2 synthesis approaches for improved photoactivity are discussed. Additionally, the surface modification of Ti3C2 through oxidation for TiO2 growth on its surface is deliberated with a detailed discussion on etchant type, concentration, etching time, and environmental factors. The optimum oxidation condition, including temperature, time, and environment for thermal treatment of Ti3C2, were also included. Lastly, the review summarizes the conclusion and future perspectives for solar energy conversion applications.
